content_elements.caption: "Miss Manners" Judith Martin
content_elements.subtitle: "Miss Manners" Judith Martin

content_elements.content: DEAR MISS MANNERS: A very long time ago, my husband and I were invited to dinner at a restaurant by a colleague of his. I had not met the colleague or his wife prior to the dinner.

The men promised they wouldn’t talk shop, but they did -- throughout the entire meal. There was no inclusion of us women. I tried to initiate a conversation with the wife, and she shut me down immediately with something along the lines of, “I’d rather listen to what the men are talking about.”
Gobsmacked, I just shrank back in the seat and ate my dinner. As my husband and I were leaving, I told him what had happened and he (rightfully) said that we’d never do that again.
I should have gotten over this by now, but I fantasize about having left the table in some way. What should I have done? I didn’t want to be rude myself.
GENTLE READER: Are you talking about a very, VERY long time ago? Because Miss Manners remembers those days -- when wives, if invited at all, were treated as table decorations to be talked around.
But didn’t we have a successful rebellion against that?
Apparently not successful enough, if it is now a wife who treats her guest like that. She need only have said, apologetically, “Sorry, I’m listening to them.”

There is no need for you to fantasize about reacting effectively, and yet not rudely, because you already did: first by your silence, and then by your and your husband’s resolving never to socialize with them again.

(Please send your questions to Miss Manners at her website, www.missmanners.com; to her email, dearmissmanners@gmail.com; or through postal mail to Miss Manners, Andrews McMeel Syndication, 1130 Walnut St., Kansas City, MO 64106.)

original.byline: Judith Martin
original.longBio: Judith Martin, who goes by the pen name of Miss Manners, is an author and columnist on etiquette authority. Martin graduated from Wellesley College with a degree in English. She began her career in writing as a journalist, covering social events at the White House and embassies, later moving on as a theater and film critic. In 1978, Martin began her advice column, answering questions about manners and etiquette. Martin was the recipient of a 2005 National Humanities Medal from President George W. Bush.

content_elements.caption: Skip the Starbucks line, and grab the fan-favorite Ninja SLUSHi ahead of the holiday weekend. Prime members can get fast and free shipping by tomorrow.
content_elements.subtitle: Ninja SLUSHi fireworks frapp from Starbucks

content_elements.content: Starbucks just lit the fuse on summer with a limited-edition Firework Frappuccino, but it’s only available through July 7.
Fortunately, you can make the same kind of frosty, festive and flavorful red, white, and blue drink with the Ninja SLUSHi 5-Preset 88 oz. Professional Frozen Drink Maker.
Check out our Amazon shopping hub for even more seasonal steals.

config.body: Depending on where you live, you may be eligible for free overnight shipping with an Amazon Prime membership.
config.headline: Ninja SLUSHi 88 oz. Frozen Drink & Slushie Machine
config.image_alt_text: Ninja SLUSHi 88 oz. Frozen Drink & Slushie Machine

content_elements.content: And, with Prime shipping options, you can get it from Amazon for $350 and have it delivered as early as tomorrow.

According to Starbucks, the refreshing and patriotic frapp features the berry flavors of Starbucks Summer-Berry Refresher blended with coconut milk and poured over raspberry-flavored pearls. It has a swirl of strawberry purée for a pop of red, and it’s topped with vanilla sweet cream cold foam.

With the Ninja SLUSHi, you can blend your own version of Starbucks’ holiday drink using juicy ingredients, the SLUSHi’s “Frappé” preset and the machine’s core RapidChill technology, which turns room-temperature liquids into frozen drinks in as little as 15 minutes — no pre-freezing required.
How to remix the Firework Frappuccino at home:

items.content: Base: Blend a berry juice or refresher-style mix with coconut milk for that creamy slash fruity foundation.
Pearls: Add raspberry-flavored popping boba (available online at stores, like Target or Walmart, or shoppable at Asian markets) for that punchy burst.
Swirl: Drizzle in strawberry purée for a bold red pop of color.
Top: Finish with a whipped vanilla cold foam easily made with milk, vanilla syrup, and a frother or whatever you can buy in a can from the supermarket.

content_elements.content: With its 88-ounce vessel, you can serve your whole crew Firecracker Frapps in one go — and it’ll keep them cold and icy for up to 12 hours.
So, whether you plan on hosting a barbecue, lounging by the pool or watching firework displays from your front porch, the 5-in-1 SLUSHi will keep the bomb-pop frozen beverage inspo flowing.

content_elements.caption: Yankees rookie catcher J.C. Escarra was charged an error for catcher's interference while the Blue Jays scored five seventh-inning runs Monday, turning a 4-4 tie into a 9-4 lead in a game that ended up 12-5.
content_elements.copyright: Copyright 2025 The Associated Press. All rights reserved.
content_elements.subtitle: Yankees Mariners Baseball

content_elements.content: TORONTO — J.C. Escarra feels personally responsible for the Yankees’ 12-5 loss to the Blue Jays on Tuesday, a game-changing catcher’s interference on a check swing.
Yankees manager Aaron Boone blamed the mistake on a rule that he feels MLB ought to change.
Reliever Luke Weaver, who allowed five seventh-inning rules immediately after the E2, agrees with his skipper.
With two on and one out in the seventh inning of a tie game, the rookie catcher knows that he was too aggressive trying to frame a 3-2 fastball from Luke Weaver that already was a framed strike.
Plate umpire Doug Eddings rung up pinch-hitter Addison Barger, but while checking his swing his bat clipped Escarra’s catcher’s mitt.

The Blue Jays asked for replay challenge to overturn the strikeout, won and wound up with the bases loaded and one out instead of two on with two down when Escarra was charged with a second catcher’s interference call in two days.
“It’s on me,” Escarra said. “I intend to get as close as possible, but obviously not letting that happen. I was too close. I didn’t help my team win today … or yesterday.
“It shouldn’t happen, but it’s something I can control. I was just too deep in there trying to steal that strike.”
Boone says the Yankees relentlessly prepare to avoid catcher’s interference by knowing which hitters are more prone to hitting a catcher’s mitt with a swing during framing situations.
“We’re incredibly diligent on trying to eliminate that as much as possible,” Boone said. “I don’t know how many times it’s happened to us this year in the first three months.
“It is something that we lean into every hitter. Who are we vulnerable with? Who are we not? We’ve met and we do that accordingly with our catchers.”
What bothered Boone is that this one occurred when Barger didn’t even swing.
“We benefited from a check swing last year,” Boone said. “I forget the game, but there should probably be something looked into that where a check swing can’t get you beat like that.”
Weaver feels the same.

“It’s pretty devastating, honestly,” he said. “I feel like that’s a really unfortunate part of our game. I don’t really personally think that belongs in our game. I think there should be some type of discretion to it.

“I understand that there are moments where it’s very egregious and (batters) hit the glove on a full swing, but you feel like you earned something there and it was taken from you and it’s out of my control at that point.
“Just a real silly thing to happen.”
After it happened, the floodgates opened with the tie-breaking hit by Clement and then the grand slam by Springer, who had a great day going 3-for-4 with two homers and seven RBI.
“I’m trying to get the groundball on the next pitch (to Clement) and it just finds the hole, then you run into a bad pitch there a guy that’s having a nice day and the game gets away from you.”
The Blue Jays taking over the game after the catcher’s interference sickened Escarra.
“Exactly,” he said. “It gave them bases loaded and the big hit came. I could have prevented it, so it was in my control.”
Yankees -1.5 runline is +128 on DraftKings for Wednesday’s game against the Blue Jays. Our comprehensive DraftKings Sportsbook review will show you how to sign up and get started.
Escarra says that he’s never had a problem with catcher’s interference calls until the last two days.

“No,” he said. “It’s just trying to get the glove in the zone. If the pitch is out of the zone, I’m just trying to move it as fast as possible up and forward to steal that strike, to make it look like a strike to the umpire.
“He wasn’t going to swing, but at the end of the day I shouldn’t have been too close like that.
“Going forward, I’ve really got to make it a priority to not get in too deep in there.”
Thank you for relying on us to provide the journalism you can trust. Please consider supporting us with a subscription.
Randy Miller may be reached at rmiller@njadvancemedia.com.

Since 1996, he's been a baseball beat writer for all by three years ... the first 16 covering the Philadelphia Phillies and since 2016 following the Yankees.
original.longBio: Randy is a native of Jeannette, Pa., a city 25 miles east of Pittsburgh, and has been writing about sports since age 15 when he was covering high schools and Pitt football for the Jeannette News-Dispatch. Since 1996, Randy has been a Major League Baseball beat writer except for three years when he covered hockey. He was on the Philadelphia Phillies beat from 1996-2011 and since 2016 has been a New York Yankees beat writer for NJ Advance Media (Newark Star-Ledger/NJ.com). Known for his dogged reporting skills, Randy has won numerous writing awards over the years. He's been a Baseball Hall of Fame voter since 2006. Away from the ballpark, Randy enjoys Bible study,  country and classic rock music, traveling ... especially to Myrtle Beach and different college football stadiums around the country (especially SEC). He's been a big Pittsburgh Penguins hockey fan since the early 1970s.

content_elements.content: On Wednesday at 2:51 a.m. the National Weather Service issued an updated flood warning in effect until 7 a.m. for Monmouth and Ocean counties.

The weather service states, "Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected for portions of central and southern New Jersey, including in central New Jersey, Monmouth counties. In southern New Jersey, Ocean."

"Flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations is imminent or occurring," explains the weather service. "Don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles."
Understanding the differences between advisories, watches, and warnings

items.content: Flash flood warning: Take action!

content_elements.content: A flash flood warning is issued when a flash flood is either imminent or already occurring. In flood-prone areas, it's crucial to move immediately to higher ground. A flash flood is a sudden and violent inundation that can develop within minutes to hours, and it can even happen in areas not currently experiencing rainfall.

items.content: Flood warning: Take action!

content_elements.content: A flood warning is declared when flooding is on the verge of happening or is already underway.

items.content: Flood advisory: Be aware:

content_elements.content: A flood advisory is released when flooding is not expected to reach a severity level necessitating a warning. Nonetheless, it can still cause considerable inconvenience and, without exercising caution, potentially lead to situations that threaten life and/or property.

items.content: Flood watch: Be prepared:

content_elements.content: A flood watch is issued when conditions are favorable for flooding. It does not mean flooding will occur, but it is possible.
When floods strike: Guidelines from the weather service for your protection

Floods can pose a significant threat, especially if you live in a flood-prone area or find yourself camping in a low-lying region. To ensure your safety, the weather service offers essential flood safety guidelines:
Move to higher ground:
If you reside in a flood-prone region or are camping in low-lying terrain, the first step to safety is relocating to higher ground.
Follow evacuation orders:
If local authorities issue an evacuation order, heed it promptly. Prior to leaving, secure your home by locking it.
Disconnect utilities and appliances:
If time permits, disconnect your utilities and appliances. This precaution minimizes electrical hazards during flooding.
Avoid basements and submerged areas:
Avoid basements or rooms submerged in water with electrical outlets or cords. Preventing electrical accidents is crucial.
Swift evacuation for your safety:
If you notice sparks or hear buzzing, crackling, snapping, or popping noises, evacuate immediately. Avoid any water that may be charged with electricity.
Stay away from floodwaters:
Never attempt to walk through floodwaters, even if they appear shallow. Just 6 inches of fast-moving water can forcefully sweep you off your feet.
Seek high ground if trapped:
Should you become trapped by moving water, reach the highest point possible and dial 911 to contact emergency services.

During heavy rainfall, the risk of flooding is heightened, especially in low-lying and flood-prone regions. Always remember never to drive through water on the road, no matter how shallow it appears. According to the weather service, as little as 12 inches of rapidly flowing water can carry away most vehicles. Prioritize your safety by staying informed and prepared.
Rainy roadways ahead: Essential safety tips for heavy rain
Rain can turn roads into hazards. Stay informed and follow these tips from the weather service to ensure safety during heavy rainfall:
Beware of swollen waterways:
During heavy rain, avoid parking or walking near culverts or drainage ditches, where swift-moving water can pose a serious risk.
Maintain safe driving distances:

Adhere to the two-second rule for maintaining a safe following distance behind the vehicle in front of you. In heavy rain, allow an additional two seconds of distance to compensate for reduced traction and braking effectiveness.
Reduce speed and drive cautiously:
On wet roads, slowing down is paramount. Gradually ease off the accelerator and avoid abrupt braking to prevent skidding.
Choose your lane wisely:
Stay toward the middle lanes - water tends to pool in the outside lanes.
Visibility matters:
Turn on your headlights and be careful of other vehicles to the rear and in blind spot areas as they are especially difficult to see through rain-spattered windows.
Watch out for slippery roads:
The first half-hour of rain is when roads are slickest due to a mix of rain, grime, and oil. Exercise heightened caution during this period.
Keep a safe distance from large vehicles:
Don't follow large trucks or buses too closely. The spray created by their large tires reduces your vision. Take care when passing them as well; if you must pass, do so quickly and safely.
Mind your windshield wipers:

items.content: Overloaded wiper blades can hinder visibility. If rain severely limits your sight, pull over and wait for conditions to improve. Seek refuge at rest areas or protected spots.

If the roadside is your only option, pull off as far as possible, preferably past the end of a guard rail, and wait until the storm passes. Keep your headlights on and turn on emergency flashers to alert other drivers of your position.

content_elements.content: By following these safety measures, you can significantly reduce risks and ensure your well-being when heavy rain pours down. Stay informed about weather conditions and heed advice from local authorities to make your journey safe and sound.

content_elements.subtitle: Eugenia Last

content_elements.content: CELEBRITIES BORN ON THIS DAY: Margot Robbie, 35; Alex Morgan, 36; Ashley Tisdale, 40; Larry David, 78.

Happy Birthday: Emotions will run wild, requiring astute attention this year. Turn the negatives you encounter into positives by searching for the best route. Attitude is everything; it only takes a smile, a suggestion and a kind gesture to get others on your side. Paint their way forward with broad strokes; be the instigator and the one offering hope and enthusiasm, and you’ll find your circle and the path that leads to victory and a better future. Your numbers are 5, 17, 21, 32, 34, 36, 45.

CANCER (June 21-July 22): Finish what you start before complaining. You must build momentum and maintain a solid grip on your goals before you face opposition. Timing is everything; leverage comes from preparing sufficiently and knowing when you can win. Keep doors open, know what others want and deliver your promises promptly. Actions speak louder than words. 2 stars

LEO (July 23-Aug. 22): Rethink what you want and how to make it happen. Put pressure on any person or situation that stands between you and your goal. Reach out, share your opinions along with your suggestions, and be willing to offer incentives or compromises to get what you want. A partnership will turn out better than anticipated. 4 stars

VIRGO (Aug. 23-Sept. 22): Slow down, give yourself a chance to think and formulate the best path forward. You will uncover facts that influence how you feel about someone. Refuse to let anger set in when dignity and grace are necessary. Life is too short to let upset people consume your mind and time. 3 stars

LIBRA (Sept. 23-Oct. 22): Overreacting is the enemy. When you feel pressured or confused, put your energy into laborious activities that result in home and self-improvement. Talking with someone you trust to give you an honest opinion will help you figure out how to handle stressful emotional scenarios. Walk away from a toxic situation. 3 stars

SCORPIO (Oct. 23-Nov. 21): Experience is the learning curve that will push you in the right direction. Participate in events that shed light on trends and help you decide if you want to be involved. Displaying an open mind will be necessary, but don’t feel obligated to donate cash. Offer your input and skills if what you learn inspires you. 3 stars

SAGITTARIUS (Nov. 22-Dec. 21): Only spend what you can afford. Concentrate on bringing in more cash and investing in your future. Maintaining a secure lifestyle will require funds to support your needs. Distance yourself from excessive or indulgent people, curb impulsive actions and keep the promises you made to yourself. 4 stars

CAPRICORN (Dec. 22-Jan. 19): Avoid making the same mistake twice. Whether you are dealing with money, love or health, choose the route that has the best track record. Be a leader, not a follower, and you’ll gain respect and the recognition you deserve. A change within will encourage those you love to follow suit. 2 stars

AQUARIUS (Jan. 20-Feb. 18): It’s up to you to bring about change and to go after what you want. Be the one to start a conversation or take a step. Share your interests and find out where you stand. You have more going for you than you realize. Be direct and follow through. Romance is in the stars. 5 stars

PISCES (Feb. 19-March 20): Let your heart lead the way, and opportunities will unfold. An energetic attitude will help you pursue happiness and manifest the life you want to live. Participate in activities that bring you closer to someone you love or, if single, help you find your soulmate. Physical improvements will exceed your expectations. 3 stars

ARIES (March 21-April 19): Proceed with caution. Someone will be easily offended if you ask too many questions or make demands. Do your own thing, participate in something intellectually stimulating and let your success and happiness shine through. The outcome will enhance your chances of spending more time with people who contribute to your success. 3 stars

TAURUS (April 20-May 20): Participate in learning, expanding your interests and fine-tuning your skills. You have plenty to gain if you engage in a group activity that offers physical health benefits that add to your appearance, strength and ability to reach personal and professional goals. Attend networking or social events that promote love and romance. 3 stars

GEMINI (May 21-June 20): Make changes at home that improve your life. Discuss issues you have with anyone who is causing you concern or grief. Face situations head-on instead of letting your stress consume you. Take control of your emotions, and do whatever’s necessary to eliminate strife and gain your desired happiness. Choose peace over discord. 5 stars
Birthday Baby: You are charming, entertaining and opportunistic. You are pioneering and speedy.

1 star: Avoid conflicts; work behind the scenes. 2 stars: You can accomplish, but don’t rely on others. 3 stars: Focus and you’ll reach your goals. 4 stars: Aim high; start new projects. 5 stars: Nothing can stop you; go for gold.

by.name: Joey Chandler
by.description: Joey Chandler is a pro and college sports reporter at NJ.com with a primary focus on sports commerce. You can also find her at Jersey Mike's Arena covering the Rutgers women's basketball team. Her work has won awards at national and state levels.

original.byline: Joey Chandler | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
original.bio: Joey Chandler is a pro and college sports reporter at NJ.com with a primary focus on sports commerce. You can also find her at Jersey Mike's Arena covering the Rutgers women's basketball team. Her work has won awards at national and state levels.
original.longBio: Joey Chandler is a pro and college sports commerce reporter at NJ.com. You can also find her at Jersey Mike's Arena covering the Rutgers women's basketball team. Chandler is in her 19th year as a sports journalist. Her work has been recognized at national and state levels. She's earned Associated Press Sports Editors honors and won first-place writing awards for features, columns and breaking news in Ohio, Alabama and North Carolina. She joined NJ.com in late April of 2021. Before arriving in New Jersey, she covered East Carolina University athletics for the Wilmington StarNews. She spent five years at the Tuscaloosa News as a preps writer, assisting with Alabama football coverage and the sports department intern program. In 2015, she was selected to take part in the APSE Diversity Fellowship program. She started her career covering high school sports in Ohio, including stops with the Mount Vernon News, Chillicothe Gazette and Bucyrus Telegraph-Forum. She graduated from Ashland University in Ashland, Ohio in 2006, majoring in sport communication and journalism.

content_elements.caption: Dear Abby is written by Abigail Van Buren, also known as Jeanne Phillips.
content_elements.subtitle: Dear Abby

content_elements.content: DEAR ABBY: After years of disappointment, I finally found the man of my dreams. How do I tell him he isn’t doing certain things right in the bedroom without it being uncomfortable? I have mentioned it before, but it didn’t stick. This is the only problem with our relationship. I don’t want to hurt his feelings or make either one of us uncomfortable, but he’s just not getting the job done. -- WORKING ON IT IN TENNESSEE

DEAR WORKING: I will assume that the man of your dreams loves you and wants to take care of you. Although this may be a difficult topic to address, communication is very important. Ask your doctor or gynecologist for a referral to a licensed sex therapist, then tell the man you love you would like him to accompany you. If he loves you, he will go and learn something. If his ego gets in the way, have the conversation about what you need at a time when you are both calm and relaxed, and communication is easier -- NOT in the bedroom.

Dear Abby is written by Abigail Van Buren, also known as Jeanne Phillips, and was founded by her mother, Pauline Phillips. Contact Dear Abby at www.DearAbby.com or P.O. Box 69440, Los Angeles, CA 90069.

by.name: Abigail  Van Buren
by.description:
Jeanne Phillips, also known as Abigail Van Buren, has written the advice column “Dear Abby” since 2000, responding with the wit and compassion that earns her the loyalty of millions of fans. She’s the daughter of Pauline Esther Phillips, who founded “Dear Abby’’ in 1956.
Contact her at www.DearAbby.com or P.O. Box 69440, Los Angeles, CA 90069.

original.byline: Abigail Van Buren
original.bio:
Jeanne Phillips, also known as Abigail Van Buren, has written the advice column “Dear Abby” since 2000, responding with the wit and compassion that earns her the loyalty of millions of fans. She’s the daughter of Pauline Esther Phillips, who founded “Dear Abby’’ in 1956.
Contact her at www.DearAbby.com or P.O. Box 69440, Los Angeles, CA 90069.
original.longBio:
Jeanne Phillips, also known as Abigail Van Buren, has written the advice column “Dear Abby” since 2000, responding knowledgeably with the wit and compassion that earns her the loyalty of millions of fans. She’s the daughter of Pauline Esther Phillips, who founded “Dear Abby’’ in 1956.
  
Jeanne Phillips began assisting her mother with the column at the age of 14, supplying advice for inquiring teens, and discovering that she loved the work. She co-wrote the column until 2002, when she assumed the role herself.  

She was born in Minneapolis, Minnesota, and lived in Wisconsin and California during her formative years. At the University of Colorado and UCLA she studied anthropology, and she holds a PhD from Columbia College in Columbia, South Carolina. 

Phillips is one of few laypersons ever to be granted a prestigious Life Consultant membership in the Group for Advancement of Psychiatry (GAP), an organization of nationally respected psychiatrists. 

She’s received awards from the National Office of Drug Policy, American Academy of Dermatology, American Ex-Prisoners of War, Overeaters Anonymous and the national Minority Organ Tissue Transplant Education Program. She is the recipient of the 2015 Proxmire Award for leadership in public awareness of Alzheimer's disease and dementia, and the Hearing Loss Association of America's 2015 Walter T. Ridder Award. In 2007, Parents, Families and Friends of Lesbians and Gays (PFLAG) honored Phillips with its first "Straight for Equality" Award for her support of LGBT equality.

original.byline: Joey Chandler | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
original.bio: Joey Chandler is a pro and college sports reporter at NJ.com with a primary focus on sports commerce. You can also find her at Jersey Mike's Arena covering the Rutgers women's basketball team. Her work has won awards at national and state levels.
original.longBio: Joey Chandler is a pro and college sports commerce reporter at NJ.com. You can also find her at Jersey Mike's Arena covering the Rutgers women's basketball team. Chandler is in her 19th year as a sports journalist. Her work has been recognized at national and state levels. She's earned Associated Press Sports Editors honors and won first-place writing awards for features, columns and breaking news in Ohio, Alabama and North Carolina. She joined NJ.com in late April of 2021. Before arriving in New Jersey, she covered East Carolina University athletics for the Wilmington StarNews. She spent five years at the Tuscaloosa News as a preps writer, assisting with Alabama football coverage and the sports department intern program. In 2015, she was selected to take part in the APSE Diversity Fellowship program. She started her career covering high school sports in Ohio, including stops with the Mount Vernon News, Chillicothe Gazette and Bucyrus Telegraph-Forum. She graduated from Ashland University in Ashland, Ohio in 2006, majoring in sport communication and journalism.

content_elements.caption: Deerhoof has begun the process of removing their music from Spotify due to the co-founder's ties to an AI battle tech company.  (Photo by Robin Little/Redferns,)
content_elements.subtitle: Deerhoof Perform At EartH Hackney

content_elements.content: Spotify has come under fire for not labeling AI-generated music that has recently flooded the streaming service.
San Francisco indie rock band Deerhoof is taking things a step further in protest of the co-founder and chief executive officer, Daniel Ek’s, investment in an AI military company.
In a statement released on the band’s Instagram account on Monday, Deerhoof announced they will be pulling their entire 20-album discography from Spotify.

“‘Daniel Ek uses $700 million of his Spotify fortune to become chairman of AI battle tech company’ was not a headline we enjoyed reading this week,” the band wrote. “We don’t want our music killing people. We don’t want our success being tied to AI battle tech.”

Ek himself is the founder of an investment fund named Prima Materia. In June, Prima Materia led an effort to raise € 600 million ($693.6 million) for Helsing, a defense company specializing in the sale of software utilizing AI to inform tactical decisions, as reported by CNBC. Ek joined the company board in 2021 and was later named chairman last month.
NJ Advance Media has reached out to Spotify for comment.

raw_oembed.html:
View this post on Instagram

A post shared by Deerhoof (@deerhoof)

content_elements.content: The members of Deerhoof also stated that they were entering a strategic partnership with DoorDash as a joke and that the band made more money from touring anyway. They later levied a critique of Spotify’s overall experience for both users and musicians.

“Spotify is flushing itself down the toilet,” the band said. “Eventually artists will want to leave this already widely hated data-mining scam masquerading as a ‘music company.’ It’s creepy for users and crappy for artists. Music-making lasts forever, but this or that digital get-rich-quick scheme is sure to become obsolete.”
As far as the takedowns are concerned, labels the band has worked with, such as Kill Rock Stars and Polyvinyl, will have to request Deerhoof’s music to be removed.

“The grunt work of pulling content off of Spotify is something they’re now tasked with, and they are sharing the financial hit, the band wrote, “We know we are asking them to make a sacrifice, and it means a lot to us.”
Joyful Noise Recordings, the label which has aided in the release of Deerhoof’s last six albums, released a statement in support of the band’s move.

“As an independent record label, we serve the artist,” Joyful Noise wrote. “It is ultimately their decision to present their material on whichever platforms they choose. It is with this in mind that we hold no judgment towards any artist that wishes to keep their music on the platform.”

original.longBio: Joey Chandler is a pro and college sports commerce reporter at NJ.com. You can also find her at Jersey Mike's Arena covering the Rutgers women's basketball team. Chandler is in her 19th year as a sports journalist. Her work has been recognized at national and state levels. She's earned Associated Press Sports Editors honors and won first-place writing awards for features, columns and breaking news in Ohio, Alabama and North Carolina. She joined NJ.com in late April of 2021. Before arriving in New Jersey, she covered East Carolina University athletics for the Wilmington StarNews. She spent five years at the Tuscaloosa News as a preps writer, assisting with Alabama football coverage and the sports department intern program. In 2015, she was selected to take part in the APSE Diversity Fellowship program. She started her career covering high school sports in Ohio, including stops with the Mount Vernon News, Chillicothe Gazette and Bucyrus Telegraph-Forum. She graduated from Ashland University in Ashland, Ohio in 2006, majoring in sport communication and journalism.

content_elements.caption: "Miss Manners" Judith Martin
content_elements.subtitle: "Miss Manners" Judith Martin

content_elements.content: DEAR MISS MANNERS: My husband’s cousin and her husband live a few miles away from us. While their parents were fairly close when the cousins were growing up, the cousins themselves didn’t maintain contact once they became adults.
I enjoy sending greeting cards for birthdays, anniversaries, holidays and so on, and this cousin is on my list. We’re also friends on social media.

She messages me and suggests that we get together for lunch sometime, but offers no specific details. I then propose a date, time and place, which she agrees to, but always cancels on the day of the meeting.
I’ve come to expect this and don’t think much of it, but it upsets my husband. Should I continue making suggestions even though I know they will likely be canceled at the last minute?

GENTLE READER: Next time the cousin proposes a get-together, give an equally vague response: “That would be great.” Breaking the pattern may or may not change her behavior, but it will give everyone something new to think about.

(Please send your questions to Miss Manners at her website, www.missmanners.com; to her email, dearmissmanners@gmail.com; or through postal mail to Miss Manners, Andrews McMeel Syndication, 1130 Walnut St., Kansas City, MO 64106.)
<adi-stories-by-section-tag adiWidgetId="widgie-24fd8778-2710-4a30-ac7b-b14ea1e3b6a2"></adi-stories-by-section-tag>

original.byline: Judith Martin
original.longBio: Judith Martin, who goes by the pen name of Miss Manners, is an author and columnist on etiquette authority. Martin graduated from Wellesley College with a degree in English. She began her career in writing as a journalist, covering social events at the White House and embassies, later moving on as a theater and film critic. In 1978, Martin began her advice column, answering questions about manners and etiquette. Martin was the recipient of a 2005 National Humanities Medal from President George W. Bush.

content_elements.caption: The Yankees can greatly improve their first-place team by moving third baseman Jazz Chisholm back to second base and trading for Diamondbacks third baseman Eugenio Suárez, who has 26 homers and 69 RBI in 83 games.
content_elements.copyright: Copyright 2025 The Associated Press. All rights reserved
content_elements.subtitle: Marlins Diamondbacks Baseball

content_elements.content: TORONTO — If you were watching Tuesday when often-unhittable Yankees ace Max Fried was shellacked for four fourth-inning runs on two homers, you saw how the Blue Jays’ big blow was set up.
After a leadoff homer by George Springer and then two outs, Davis Schneider hit a chopper to third base that should have had the Yankees off the field up a run.

Jazz Chisholm hustled in to field the grounder on two hops, then whipped an off-balance throw to first that was way off target. First baseman Paul Goldschmidt had to leave the bag to catch the throw, which was five feet to the home plate side of first, and the Blue Jays had a two-out baserunner on a fairly routine groundball that should have been scored an error but gifted Schneider a cheap hit.
Watching this play out, did you say for the umpteenth time in the last month:
Why the hell did the Yankees move Chisholm from second base to third last month?

When a walk to Miles Straw and then a Andres Giminez three-run homer to dead center followed Chisholm’s mess up, the Blue Jays were up two runs in a Canada Day matinee that Toronto won 12-5 to get to within one game of the first-place Yanks.
This 12th Yankees defeat in their last 18 games again showed they’re a ballclub with problems that need addressed.
They need bullpen help, they’ve hit a dreadful .118 with runners in scoring potion over their last 19 games, Anthony Volpe now has fielding woes in addition to inconsistent hitting and …
The Yankees need to flip Chisholm and second baseman DJ LeMahieu immediately,
And then general manager Brian Cashman needs to make it a mission to deal for a better third baseman before the July 31 trade deadline.
It makes no sense why Chisholm was pulled off second in the first place. That’s his best position by far. He’s good there. He’s not good at third.
Chisholm would rather play second, too, but he’s all about whatever’s best for the team, so he’ll play wherever with no complaints.
And while LeMahieu won Gold Gloves in his heyday and has done OK there since he started his season in mid-May, he’ll be 36 on July 13 ... an old 36.
LeMahieu just doesn’t have close to the range that Chisholm has there. Also, LeMahieu showed that he can handle third during those rare occasions when he was off the IL the last few seasons.
Chisholm has been charged with only three errors in his 25 games at third base, all since June 3, but he’s botched a few plays that were scored hits.
He even looks like a fish out of water at third.
Why switch?

The Yankees probably were catering to LeMahieu because they’re desperate to get some payback for the $15 million that he’ll make annually this year and again in 2026, mercifully the last season of a six-year, $90-million contract that hasn’t worked out at all.
This might not have been manager Aaron Boone’s decision, either.

The wild guess here is that Yankees management and/or their analytics department’s fingerprints are on this because Boone hasn’t given a good answer when he was asked why Chisholm was pulled off second.
But now that it’s very apparent that Chisholm needs to return to second, it needs to happen.
After Tuesday’s game, Boone was asked if there will be consideration returning Chisholm to second and playing LeMahieu at third.
“We’ll talk through that stuff,” Boone responded. “I think both guys are really talented defenders wherever they line up, but we’ll continue to look at things like that.”
That answer was telling.
Taking a stab on what’s going on privately, the Yankees perhaps have been seriously thinking of making this switch.
Or maybe Boone and his coaching staff are pushing for it to happen.
If Chisholm goes back to second, the Yankees immediately become much better up the middle because he’s the better defender.
The Yankees then still would need to address third base because LeMahieu, like past season, again looks far beyond his prime years batting .250 with two homers and 11 RBI in 40 games.
The Yankees weren’t expecting LeMahieu to hit this season like he did when he won two batting championships, but they were hoping for more offensive impact than they’re getting.
Maybe LeMahieu will stay off the IL, get hot and hit in the high .200s because he’s only being judged now on 116 at-bats. If it does, it couldn’t happen to a better guy.
But he’s just not passing the eye test often enough to warrant regular at-bats.

Unfortunately for the Yankees, reserve infielder Oswald Peraza isn’t the answer, either. He can pick it anywhere in the infield as well as almost anyone, but the bat never has come around and it’s probably time to cut the cord on a one-time elite prospect who hasn’t panned out.

In the coming weeks, the pressure will be on Cashman to improve the Yankees’ roster because returning to the World Series is there for the taking with only the AL Central-power Tigers, AL West-leading Astros and maybe AL East rival Blue Jays and Rays in their way.

Cashman surely will add one or two bullpen arms, the expected August return of Luis Gil should give the rotation a big boost and a right-handed bat with power may be brought in to get left field starts because rookie switch-hitter Jasson Dominguez is much better now from the left side.
Third base?

If Chisholm does go back to second, Cashman’s best available play would be trading with the Diamondbacks for star third baseman Eugenio Suarez, who is have a great season. At age 33, he’s among the NL homer (26) and RBI (69) leaders while hitting a respectable .254 and playing a solid third base.
In addition to Suarez’s bat and fielding being very attractive, his contract is, too. The Venezuelan is making $15 million in his walk season to free agency.

There probably will be a lot of competition for Suarez assuming the 43-42 Diamondbacks are sellers. For sure, they’d demand Cashman’s offer include Yankees No. 1 prospect George Lombard Jr., a 20-year-old Double-A shortstop who has star potential.

That won’t happen, but the Diamondbacks might take No. 2 prospect Spencer Jones, a 6-foot-7 center fielder who just recently went to Triple-A, plus one of the SEC arms that was drafted early last summer.
Whatever happens at the deadline, the Yankees can improve NOW by putting Chisholm back where he belongs ... second base.
Thank you for relying on us to provide the journalism you can trust. Please consider supporting us with a subscription.
Randy Miller may be reached at rmiller@njadvancemedia.com.

original.longBio: Randy is a native of Jeannette, Pa., a city 25 miles east of Pittsburgh, and has been writing about sports since age 15 when he was covering high schools and Pitt football for the Jeannette News-Dispatch. Since 1996, Randy has been a Major League Baseball beat writer except for three years when he covered hockey. He was on the Philadelphia Phillies beat from 1996-2011 and since 2016 has been a New York Yankees beat writer for NJ Advance Media (Newark Star-Ledger/NJ.com). Known for his dogged reporting skills, Randy has won numerous writing awards over the years. He's been a Baseball Hall of Fame voter since 2006. Away from the ballpark, Randy enjoys Bible study,  country and classic rock music, traveling ... especially to Myrtle Beach and different college football stadiums around the country (especially SEC). He's been a big Pittsburgh Penguins hockey fan since the early 1970s.

additional_properties.originalName: Mitch Williams and Darren Daulton at 2013 reunion.jpg

content_elements.caption: Former Phillies players Mitch Williams (left) and the late Darren Daulton during the 2013 reunion of the franchise's 1993 National League champions.
content_elements.subtitle: Mitch Williams, Darren Daulton

content_elements.content: The Phillies’ game with the San Diego Padres Tuesday night was postponed and rescheduled as a day-night doubleheader Wednesday, a fitting way to celebrate the 32nd anniversary of perhaps the most peculiar twin bill in the history of the franchise.

On July 2, 1993, the Phillies and Padres played what they used to call a twi-night doubleheader with the first game scheduled for 4:35 p.m. (it was delayed nine minutes by rain) and the second game scheduled to begin about 20 minutes after the first one.
The second game ended at 4:40 a.m., which remains the latest a major-league game has ever ended.
Fireworks, as they are again Wednesday at Citizens Bank Park, were also in the plans after the two games at Veterans Stadium more than three decades ago.
Nothing went as planned.

The first game only took 2 hours and 34 minutes, but it didn’t end until after 1 a.m. because of three different rain delays that lasted 5 hours and 54 minutes. At the time, there were no rules about how late the second game could start.
Crew chief Dana DeMuth said play ball and Jose DeLeon threw the first pitch at 1:28 a.m.

Mitch Williams, the Phillies’ closer known for his violent fall-off-the-mound delivery and often chaotic ninth innings, would eventually emerge as the unlikely hero who ended the 12-hour marathon, but he spent most of the crazy event as a spectator.
He had hoped to have a role in one of the games because his father and stepmother had flown in from Oregon that day to see him pitch.
“They had flew all day from Oregon,” Williams told NJ Advance Media via telephone Tuesday from his Texas home.

Williams didn’t pitch in the first game, a 5-2 Phillies loss and his stepmother left in the middle of the third and final rain delay with Williams’ wife Irene. When the game ended, Williams met his father outside the clubhouse and informed him the second game would start in 20 minutes.
“He said, ‘It might start for you, but I’m done,’ ” Williams said. “He said, ‘Give me the keys to your truck. I had like a queen size bed in the back of my truck.”
Around 4 a.m., Irene Williams got a call from her mother Pat at home in Moorestown.

“She says, ‘Irene, I know you’re sleeping ... but Mitch is about to come up and bat,’ ” Williams’ wife remembered Tuesday. “I was like, ‘Mom, what are you talking about? You know it’s four o’clock in the morning.’ She said, ‘Turn on the TV, they’re still playing.”

Williams, after pitching two scoreless innings, was told by manager Jim Fregosi before the bottom of the 10th inning of Game 2 that his evening as a pitcher was over, but that he’d have to hit if his spot came up in the order because the Phillies were out of position players. Fregosi had also burned his two best hitting pitchers — Tommy Greene and David West.
Sure enough, Williams’ turn in the order came up.

“A lot of people who knew me knew that all I wanted to do was hit,” Williams said. “I loved taking BP and I always wanted to get into a game and hit. I lived to do that. I used to pay people to throw me BP.”
That doesn’t mean he was an especially good hitter. He finished his career with three hits (one was a three-run homer off the Mets’ Don Aase) in 17 plate appearances.

With the birds chirping as dawn approached on this July night in South Philadelphia, Williams had the tall task of facing San Diego’s Trevor Hoffman, a rookie who had only accumulated two of what would become 601 career saves.
Even then, however, he had one of the nastiest changeups in the game.
“I remember going up to the plate and telling the catcher (Kevin Higgins) that if Trevor Hoffman threw me one changeup I was going to hit him in the head with a bat,” Williams said.
Hoffman threw two fastballs and Williams lined the second one into left-center field for a game-winning single.
Williams’ father slept through it all outside in the back of his son’s truck.

“When I came out after the game he said, ‘Well, what happened?’ ” Williams said. “I said, ‘Ah nothing. I got the win in the second game and I hit a double in extra innings to win it.’ He says, ‘B.S.’ He couldn’t believe he was in the truck sleeping while it was going on.”
The players in the Phillies’ clubhouse after that game were understandably exhausted and it was a sentiment felt throughout the stadium.
“It’s been 50 years since I stayed out all night,” 73-year-old security guard Dewitt Hobbs told me that night.
John Kruk, the best quote in the clubhouse, declined to speak because he said “I’m going to ice so I can get home before the sun rises.”
It was a Saturday morning, so pitcher Terry Mulholland, who started the first game of the doubleheader, thought he might have to “wait for the shore traffic to die down” before he went home.
The excitement wasn’t over for Williams and his father Jeff once they left the stadium.
On his way back to South Jersey that morning, Williams was stopped by the police on the Betsy Ross Bridge.

“My dad’s laying in the back and I get pulled over,” Williams said. “My dad is like, ‘What did you do?’ I said, ‘This guy just wants to talk to me about the game.’ And sure enough he came up and he says, ‘I was listening on the radio.’ I got pulled over 16 times in 1993 on the Betsy Ross Bridge just so they could talk to me about the game. They knew my teal-colored truck so every time I went over they’d pull me over.”

It was an enchanted season for the Phillies, who spent all but one day in first place en route to a National League pennant that came courtesy of a six-game win over the Atlanta Braves in the National League Championship Series.

Their championship dream was shattered by a series-ending home run by Joe Carter off Williams in Game 6 of the World Series inside Toronto’s SkyDome, but you got the feeling those Phillies would have a special connection that would last a lifetime.

Reality has been much different and Williams is one of the Phillies estranged from his former team. Through the years, he has feuded with Curt Schilling and Lenny Dykstra and he did not attend the 30-year reunion for the 1993 team a couple seasons ago and he said the only former teammate he has kept in touch with is third baseman David Hollins.
Williams, 60, lives in Hamilton Texas, which is about 120 miles southwest of Dallas and he’s raising pigs, chickens and goats with his wife Irene.

“I haven’t watched a game or heard about a game in a long time,” Williams said. “I was kind of forced out of it. They didn’t want me to come to any of the reunions or anything. We were uninvited to the reunions except for the 30-year one. I can only get treated like crap for so long before you just walk away. At one point they wouldn’t let my family come and then they uninvited me.”
Williams said the separation leaves him both sad and angry.

“Yeah, I would have worked for that organization for the rest of my career,” he said. “They talk about Phillies’ family and everything, but we sure weren’t a part of it. It seemed like they hired everybody from that team to do something with the organization except me.I tried to get a job in broadcasting with them and they didn’t want any part of me there. When I was working at Comcast, I just wanted to do games and they wouldn’t let me do it.”

original.longBio: Bob Brookover has been the Eagles beat reporter at NJ Advance Media since November of 2023. He joined the organization as a Giants beat writer in September 2022 after a 40-year career covering Philadelphia professional sports teams for the Camden Courier Post, the Delaware County Daily Times and the Philadelphia Inquirer. He spent 21 years at the Inquirer as a beat writer for the Phillies and Eagles as well as a baseball and general sports columnist. He has won awards from the New Jersey Press Association, Keystone Media and the Associated Press Sports Editors. content_elements.alt_text: Mets, Griffin Canning, Mavericks, Klay Thompson
content_elements.caption: Mets starter Griffin Canning plans on reaching out to Dallas Mavericks guard Klay Thompson regarding his recently repaired achilles injury.
content_elements.subtitle: Mets' Griffin Canning, Mavericks' Klay Thompson

content_elements.content: NEW YORK — Mets starter Griffin Canning is already working on his recovery plan.

Back in the Mets locker room at Citi Field after successfully undergoing surgery to repair a ruptured Achilles on Tuesday, his right leg in a cast and in crutches, Canning revealed he’s already utilizing his connections to best maneuver his recovery.

“I’m good friends with Trayce Thompson, so he kinda connected me with his brother,” Canning told reporters in his usual calm demeanor. “It’s pretty early in the stages at this point. I have some questions, so I’m going to reach out to Klay (Thompson) for sure.”

Klay, the Dallas Mavericks shooting guard, knows what it feels like to have a promising season cut short by a devastating injury. He tore his ACL on his left knee in Game 6 of the 2019 NBA Finals, a game in which he led in scoring with 30 points.
He tore his Achilles while attempting to come back the following season. Klay returned to the NBA after missing two seasons
Canning left last Thursday’s game against the Atlanta Braves with a ruptured left Achilles tendon while breaking toward a grounder off the bat of shortstop Nick Allen to the left side of the infield.

He was in the middle of a resurgent season, where he was 7-3 with a 3.77 ERA and 70 strikeouts in 16 starts. The win total and ERA represent career highs for the 29-year-old, and at that strikeout rate, he was on pace to set a high in strikeouts, too.

“It sucks. I want to be out there with the guys,” Canning said. I mean, I just love baseball, so I think that’s probably the worst part, that I just don’t get to play for a while. Been doing some research, reading up on some of the basketball players who have had this.”
Mets moneyline is -130 on BetMGM for Wednesday’s 1:10 PM game against the Brewers. Our comprehensive BetMGM Sportsbook review provides a guide on how to use their app.

content_elements.caption: A veteran American League scout thinks the Yankees' future middle infield should have No. 1 prospect George Lombard Jr., at shortstop and Anthony Volpe at second base.
content_elements.subtitle: Anthony Volpe, George Lombard Jr.

content_elements.content: TORONTO — Yankees manager Aaron Boone spent a good portion of his Tuesday pre-game media availability defending his shortstop.

The night before, while the Blue Jays were staging a game-changing rally in a 5-4 win, Anthony Volpe made a bad throw that added to alarming fielding numbers that rank dead last among American League shortstops, 11 errors with a .961 fielding percentage.

The 2023 Gold Glove winner and 2024 Gold Glove finalist still is elite defender, Boone insisted even though the analytical numbers also show a drop-off, his minus-1 in Baseball Savant’s Outs Above Average and his plus-2 in Fan Graphs’ Defensive Runs Saved.
“Moving forward, I think he’s an elite defensive shortstop,” Boone said. “That’s what he is. He’s made a few errors that he hasn’t typically made. It’s a few plays.
“Nothing’s changed with who he is as a defender. Hopefully that levels out in the second half and it’s more in line. But the bottom line is he’s a playmaker out there and I expect that to continue.”
As for Volpe’s offensive contributions, Boone pushed back hard on criticism here that’s been trending on X.

“While everyone loses their mind about things, he’s a really good productive player,” Boone said. “Even offensively through some of his struggles this year, he’s a little better than league average performer at any position, let alone the shortstop position.”

“We’re fortunate to have a really good one in Anthony Volpe. That doesn’t mean we don’t expect and want him to continue to get better and better. He’s 24. Everyone’s trajectories a little bit different.

“You see late bloomers sometimes offensively. Sometimes you see a steady ascent. I think he’s a better offensive player now than he was last year and the year before, and hopefully that plays itself out the rest of the way.”

Volpe then went out and had a bad Canada Day performance in another Yankees loss, this one a 12-5 Blue Jays win. In five hitless at-bats, Volpe was at the plate three times with two runners on base and once with a man on second.
The total for Wednesday’s Yankees versus Blue Jays game is currently set at 8.5 on FanDuel. Our FanDuel Sportsbook review provides a full guide on how to sign up and navigate through their site.
He’s now batting .225 for the season, .209 in 91 at-bats with runners in scoring position. Even his steals and stolen base percentage are down.

All the while, Yankees’ No. 1 prospect George Lombard Jr., is a 20-year-old shortstop out of Gulliver Prep in Miami that’s already playing Double-A ball. He’s not tearing it up yet for the Somerset Patriots, but this son of a former big leaguer is holding his own competing with and against players who mostly are a few years older.

While the Yankees continue to wait for Volpe to grow into the star player they think he’ll be, a lot of impatient fans are excited about Lombard, who could be their future shortstop or third baseman if he’s not traded away for potential instant gratification, which is very unlikely.
“I’m hearing that Lombard is the closest thing to untouchable that the Yankees have in their system,” a veteran American League scout told NJ Advance Media on Tuesday.
What should the Yankees do with Volpe?
Who’s their shortstop of the future?
The AL scout isn’t permitted by his club to talk about other organization’s players, but was willing to share his strong opinions after being granted anonymity.
Who’s the better shortstop?

“Lombard is a better fielder than Volpe,” the scout shot back. “The hands work better. The feet work better. Better arm, and it’s not even close. The timing is better. Lombard’s more fluid. His fielding is crisp, clean and absolutely outstanding.”
What about Volpe?
“Volpe is a second baseman, not a shortstop,” the scout said.
What about Volpe winning a Gold Glove and being a finalist in his first two seasons?
“Here’s what I have to say about Gold Gloves now,” the scout said. “Juan Soto was a Gold Glove finalist last year. Gold Gloves to me aren’t what they used to be.
“Are you going to tell me Volpe was a better fielder than Gunnar Henderson or Bobby Witt in any of the last two seasons. He wasn’t.

“I wouldn’t take Volpe over Witt, Henderson, Carlos Correa and a few others. I think Volpe is an average defender at best. I think the arm is below average, but he has good timing, so it’s just enough.
“I just think Volpe is a better fit at second base. I’m not trying to be negative. I like Volpe as a player. I love him as an individual. I just think the New York Yankees need a better shortstop.”
When Lombard is ready?
“Yeah,” the scout said. “I think Lombard at shortstop with Volpe at second could be pretty damn good. But Lombard is at least a year away.
“This is his first taste in Double-A and he’s taking his lumps because he’s 20 years old. He needs to learn patience, but he’s fast tracking.”
Why has Volpe struggled with the glove?
“It seems like the game has sped up on him this year,” the scout said. “I feel like his timing was better last year.”

What about Volpe’s hitting? His .712 OPS is up from .657 last year and .666 in 2023, but his .225 average is a big drop from last season’s .243 and his 24.9 strikeout rate is up from last season’s 22.6.

“I’m seeing a little man trying to hit like Aaron Judge, and that’s not his game,” the scout said. “He used to be a gap to gap, but now he thinks he’s a power hitter. You can get away with that some at Yankee Stadium, but he’s striking out a ton and maybe will hit you 20 homers. Is that what you’re looking for.
“Volpe can run. Why not be a gap-to-gap hitter like he was and possibly hit 15 homers instead of trying to be a mini–Aaron Judge?"
What’s the offensive potential of Lombard, who will represent the Yankees in this year’s Futures Game, which will be played in Atlanta on July 12, three days before the All-Star Game.
“If we’re doing a 20/80 scale, it’s a 60 bat for Lombard,” the scout said. “This guy has a quick swing, he has bat speed and he’s strong. He’ll hit .260 and above. He’ll be a 20-plus homer guy.
“Defensively, I don’t know if he’ll win gold gloves, but he’ll be a plus defender.”
So far this season, Lombard is hitting .209 with two homers in 48 Double-A after beginning the season with High-A Hudson Valley batting .329 with one homer in 24 games.
Defensively, the 2024 first-round draft pick’s fielding numbers are very good:
Four errors and a .981 fielding percentage in 59 games at shortstop plus no errors in six games at third base.
Like the scout, Boone is a big fan of Lombard after seeing a lot of him this spring.

“I’m super excited about George,” Boone said. “I think he’s going to be a really good player in this league ... a two-way player. Outstanding defender. Runs well. The bat keeps coming. He keeps getting better and better. You really notice the physicality of him. He’s 20 years old and you see that year-to year development.
“He loves the game. He works incredibly hard at it. He plays hard. He’s one of those guys that you want driving your culture. He’s that kind of special-makeup kid.

“As advanced as he is defensively … he’s a special defender. In the spring we played him all over just to get him in there more often. He profiles as an outstanding defensive shortstop, but you just throw him over third and throw him over to second and he plays those positions like he’s been there all his life, too.
“I can’t say enough good things about George Lombard Jr., honestly. I’m so excited for his future.”

original.bio: Randy has been a big baseball fan since he was seven in Jeannette, Pa., and the 1971 Pittsburgh Pirates won the World Series. He started writing for his hometown newspaper at age 15 in 1979. Since 1996, he's been a baseball beat writer for all by three years ... the first 16 covering the Philadelphia Phillies and since 2016 following the Yankees.
original.longBio: Randy is a native of Jeannette, Pa., a city 25 miles east of Pittsburgh, and has been writing about sports since age 15 when he was covering high schools and Pitt football for the Jeannette News-Dispatch. Since 1996, Randy has been a Major League Baseball beat writer except for three years when he covered hockey. He was on the Philadelphia Phillies beat from 1996-2011 and since 2016 has been a New York Yankees beat writer for NJ Advance Media (Newark Star-Ledger/NJ.com). Known for his dogged reporting skills, Randy has won numerous writing awards over the years. He's been a Baseball Hall of Fame voter since 2006. Away from the ballpark, Randy enjoys Bible study,  country and classic rock music, traveling ... especially to Myrtle Beach and different college football stadiums around the country (especially SEC). He's been a big Pittsburgh Penguins hockey fan since the early 1970s.

original.bio: Joey Chandler is a pro and college sports reporter at NJ.com with a primary focus on sports commerce. You can also find her at Jersey Mike's Arena covering the Rutgers women's basketball team. Her work has won awards at national and state levels.
original.longBio: Joey Chandler is a pro and college sports commerce reporter at NJ.com. You can also find her at Jersey Mike's Arena covering the Rutgers women's basketball team. Chandler is in her 19th year as a sports journalist. Her work has been recognized at national and state levels. She's earned Associated Press Sports Editors honors and won first-place writing awards for features, columns and breaking news in Ohio, Alabama and North Carolina. She joined NJ.com in late April of 2021. Before arriving in New Jersey, she covered East Carolina University athletics for the Wilmington StarNews. She spent five years at the Tuscaloosa News as a preps writer, assisting with Alabama football coverage and the sports department intern program. In 2015, she was selected to take part in the APSE Diversity Fellowship program. She started her career covering high school sports in Ohio, including stops with the Mount Vernon News, Chillicothe Gazette and Bucyrus Telegraph-Forum. She graduated from Ashland University in Ashland, Ohio in 2006, majoring in sport communication and journalism.

content_elements.content: The ink was flowing in Piscataway last month.
The Rutgers football program signed multiple assistant coaches to contract extensions in June, according to documents obtained by NJ Advance Media via public records requests.
Here are the coaches who signed new deals, how much they will get paid and how long they will run for:
Co-defensive coordinator Robb Smith: Through the 2026 season. He will make a total of $1.55 million in those two seasons: $750,000 this fall and $800,000 next year.

Co-defensive coordinator Zach Sparber: Through the 2027 season. He will make a total of $2.25 million in those three seasons: $700,000 this fall, $750,000 next year and $800,000 during the 2027 season.
Tight ends coach Scott Vallone: Through the 2026 season. He will make a total of $625,000 in those two seasons: $300,000 this fall and $325,000 next year.
Defensive ends coach Julian Campenni: Through the 2026 season. He will make a total of $575,000 in those two seasons: $275,000 this fall and $300,000 next year.
Defensive tackles coach Charlie Noonan: Through the 2026 season. He will make a total of $525,000 in those two seasons: $250,000 this fall and $275,000 next year.
Cornerbacks coach David Rowe: Through the 2026 season. He will make a total of $525,000 in those two seasons: $250,000 this fall and $275,000 next year.
Rutgers made a pair of key hires on its staff this offseason, and they signed their deals last month as well:
Safeties coach Vic Hall (replacing Drew Lascari): Through the 2026 season. He will make a total of $525,000 in those two seasons: $250,000 this fall and $275,000 next year.
Player Development/Quality Control coach John McNulty (replacing John Perry): Through the 2025 season. He will make $250,000 in the only year on his current deal.
Here is where the rest of the coaching staff’s contracts stand:

Offensive coordinator Kirk Ciarrocca (signed January 2025): Through the 2027 season. He will make a total of $5.85 million in those three seasons: $1.9 million this fall, $1.95 million next year and $2 million during the 2027 season.

Wide receivers coach Dave Brock (signed January 2025): Through the 2027 season. He will make a total of $2.4 million in those three seasons: $700,000 this fall, $800,000 next year and $900,000 during the 2027 season.
Offensive line coach Pat Flaherty (signed July 31, 2024): Through the 2025 season. He will make $500,000 in the final year of his current deal.

Running backs coach Damiere Shaw (signed January of 2025): Through the 2027 season. He will make a total of $1.8 million in those three seasons: $500,000 this fall, $600,000 next year and $700,000 during the 2027 season.
Defensive line coach Colin Ferrell (signed February 2024): Through the 2025 season. He will make $300,000 in the final year of his current deal.
Please subscribe now and support the local journalism YOU rely on and trust.
Brian Fonseca may be reached at bfonseca@njadvancemedia.com.

content_elements.content: The Milwaukee Bucks have waived nine-time NBA All-Star Damian Lillard and are moving on from him in an attempt to rebuild the team around Giannis Antetokounmpmo, as first reported by ESPN’s Shams Charania.
The Bucks are stretching the $113 million remaining on his contract in order to sign former Indiana Pacers forward Myles Turner to a four-year contract.
Lillard suffered a torn Achilles during the NBA playoffs, but more than 20 teams have expressed interest in him, per ESPN’s Marc J. Spears.
Below are the current and opening numbers for Lillard’s next team, as well as the latest retirement chances, per the betting site.

original.longBio:
Adam Zagoria is a Basketball Insider who covers hoops at all levels -- NBA, College and Recruiting. For NJ.com, he has written about how projected No. 1 NBA Draft pick Cooper Flagg wasn’t born a basketball star. In fact, the nation’s top prospect was lucky to have been born at all. He covered former Seton Hall star isaiah Whitehead's harrowing escape from Israel after the Oct. 7 Hamas attack caused Whitehead to hear missiles and  bombs going off. And he has written about how an army of NBA scouts are expected this season for Rutgers' freshmen Ace Bailey and Dylan Harper.

In his free time, Adam has played in the National and World Championships in Ultimate Frisbee, and has seen more rock concerts than he cares to count.

He is the author of two books and is an award-winning filmmaker.

by.name: Tribune Content Agency

content_elements.subtitle: Asking Eric - R. Eric Thomas

content_elements.content: DEAR ERIC: My kiddo is hardworking, makes friends everywhere and is working on her third advanced degree. She is also working full time and volunteers at a shelter and her professional organization. She owns her house. My problem is her husband. He is not good enough for her.

He has also been working on an advanced degree that took him five years to complete as he was “too anxious” to present his research findings. He does nothing around the house except cook (she has to clean up) and play video games on a very expensive set-up. He was in another state for a while for research and it took my kiddo and I an entire day to clean his office. The floor was covered with fast-food wrappers and trash. We found 15 pairs of sneakers.
His field is sports-related but he does nothing physical as he has “old injuries”.

She tells me he is a lot like me and that makes me furious. She says it makes him sad to know I don’t love him. She and I have had lots of talks about him as I have been too blunt on occasion. I told her that I would try to see him as she does but I just can’t seem to get past the fact he is lazy and entitled.
I think it would be best if he and I sat down and talked but I am afraid he will go back to her with bad information. Please help me work through this.
– Worried Mom
DEAR MOM: Listen to what she’s actually telling you: she loves her husband, she loves you and your critiques are creating an issue where there isn’t one.

Your laundry list of complaints about her husband are your complaints, not hers. Yes, he has some growing to do. But I struggle to see what’s so egregious that your daughter should, what, get a divorce?
We can express opinions to loved ones, respectfully and when asked for, but – absent conditions of neglect, abuse or illegal behavior – let people do what they want to do with their love lives.
I don’t see anything that indicates your daughter is asking you for help out of this situation. In fact, it sounds like she’s having talks with you because your bluntness has become a problem.

So, it’s not a good idea for you to sit down and talk with him. It doesn’t sound like you want to build a relationship with this person. It sounds like you want to excoriate him. Instead, start by respecting the choice that your daughter made and respecting the fact that you don’t know everything about what’s going on inside of this marriage.

DEAR ERIC: I am writing after reading the letter about how to handle beautiful greeting cards you don’t want to just throw away (“Greeting Cards”). I’d love to suggest an option that, for me, is heartwarming. When I feel the love expressed, I turn the card over and on the back write a little note. Example: “Dear ___, you sent me this card on my 80th birthday and it touched my heart. Thank you. (personal note follows). Love Forever.” Then I place the card in a folder to be distributed to the sender when I pass away. I have an individual folder for each family member. It’s my hope that they’ll feel the love returned even after I am gone.
– Feeling the Love
DEAR LOVE: Oh wow! The foresight and creativity of this solution took my breath away. I simply adore this! You’ve created a sort of ouroboros of love, looping back on itself forever.

Others suggested that children’s hospitals, senior centers and schools may have donation programs set up for repurposing old cards. And – important! – I used the term “throw out” in my original answer. Let me clarify: if you’re throwing the cards out, throw them in the recycling bin.
(Send questions to R. Eric Thomas at eric@askingeric.com or P.O. Box 22474, Philadelphia, PA 19110. Follow him on Instagram and sign up for his weekly newsletter at rericthomas.com.)

original.byline: R. Eric Thomas
original.longBio:
R. Eric Thomas (he/him) is a national bestselling author, playwright, and screenwriter. His memoir, Here for It, or How to Save Your Soul in America, which Lin-Manuel Miranda hailed as “pop culture-obsessed, David Sedaris-level laugh-out-loud funny”, was featured on Today as a Read With Jenna club pick. His YA novel, Kings of B’more, was named a 2023 Stonewall Honor book by the American Library Association and his latest book of essays, Congratulations, the Best Is Over! was an instant USA Today Bestseller.
For four years, he wrote “Eric Reads the News” a daily humor column covering pop culture and politics on ELLE.com, garnering millions of devoted readers. More recently, he gained fans as an interim Prudie for Slate.com’s advice column Dear Prudence. On screen, Eric has written on the Peabody Award-winning series Dickinson on AppleTV+ and Better Things on FX and has multiple film and TV projects currently in development. Eric is also the long-running host of The Moth StorySlams in Philadelphia and has been heard multiple times on The Moth Radio Hour, NPR’s Fresh Air, All Things Considered, and Pop Culture Happy Hour. Website: rericthomas.com

content_elements.caption: Philadelphia Phillies starting pitcher Zack Wheeler throws during the first inning of a baseball game against the New York Mets, Friday, June 20, 2025, in Philadelphia. (AP Photo/Laurence Kesterson) AP
content_elements.copyright: Copyright 2025 The Associated Press. All rights reserved.
content_elements.subtitle: Mets Phillies Baseball

content_elements.content: PHILADELPHIA - Zack Wheeler has been one of the best pitchers in baseball since joining the Phillies prior to the 2020 season.

He has been runner-up in the National League Cy Young voting twice and has also been a two-time All-Star. When National League rosters are announced on Sunday, it would be a shock - not to mention a travesty - if Wheeler didn’t make his third All-Star team.
Considering his stature as one of baseball’s best pitchers and the fact this year’s All-Star Game is in his hometown of Atlanta, Wheeler would make sense as a potential All-Star Game starter.
“Just being an All-Star in general is an honor,” said Wheeler after pitching eight shutout innings in a 4-0 win over the San Diego Padres Monday. “I’ll let them figure that out.”
The other obvious choice would be Pittsburgh phenom Paul Skenes, who started last year’s game as a rookie and along with Wheeler is a front-runner for this year’s Cy Young Award.
Overall, Wheeler has an 8-3 record and 2.27 ERA. Skenes has a 4-7 record and 2.12 ERA.
If the Pirates stay in rotation - no guarantee with two off days - Skenes would pitch the final day of the first half and be ineligible to pitch in the All-Star Game.

It would make plenty of sense, especially considering the Pirates are buried in the standings, to tweak the rotation so Skenes can appear in the Mid-Summer Classic as he is one of baseball’s biggest stars and doesn’t have many opportunities to showcase himself to the country playing for Pittsburgh.

If the Phillies stay in rotation, Wheeler would pitch next Saturday, giving him two days off before a potential All-Star appearance or start. They could also adjust the rotation by having Wheeler pitch on his regular day, Friday - though that would require flip-flopping him with Ranger Suarez, who could also be an All-Star.

Despite being selected twice, Wheeler’s All-Star appearances have been limited. He struck out the only batter he faced on three pitches in 2021 and didn’t go to the game last year because of a minor injury - though he was scheduled to pitch the Sunday before the game and wouldn’t have appeared any way.
Suarez was injured last year and was not able to pitch in his first All-Star appearance.

“I’ve said all along I hope all our guys make the All-Star team because it’s a great honor, and if they want to pitch, we’ll do everything we can to let them pitch,” said Phillies manager Rob Thomson.

Wheeler is coming off a June that will likely earn him Pitcher of the Month honors. He allowed just two earned runs in 31 innings with 42 strikeouts, a month Thomson said was the best he’s ever seen from a pitcher he coached or managed.
Bill Evans can be reached atbevans@njadvancemedia.com. Follow him at@bybillevans.
