content_elements.caption: Rutgers University selected former Louisiana State University President William F. Tate IV as the school’s new president.
content_elements.subtitle: Incoming Rutger President William Tate speaks

content_elements.content: Rutgers University’s new president will earn $1.45 million in salary and bonuses over the next year under a record-setting compensation package that also includes a historic house, a car and driver, and other perks that come with leading the state university.
William F. Tate IV — who started working for Rutgers on Tuesday — will make $1.1 million in base salary his first year, according to his contract.

Tate will be Rutgers’ highest-paid president ever. He will earn nearly $200,000 more a year in base salary alone when compared to his predecessor Jonathan Holloway, who officially stepped down from the job earlier this week.
Holloway was earning $919,639 after five years as president, Rutgers officials said.

items.content: MORE: Rutgers’ new president enters a university under immense pressure. Can he take the heat?

content_elements.content: Tate will also top his own previous salary by more than 40%. In his last job at Louisiana State University, where Tate served as president for the past four years, his base pay was $750,000.

Tate agreed to a five-year deal with Rutgers, though the contract says he serves “at the pleasure of the Board of Governors.” That means there is no guarantee he will be asked to stay the full five years.
Here are the key terms of Tate’s deal with Rutgers:
Bonuses
Tate will be eligible for a performance bonus each year. In his first year on the job, he will receive the maximum bonus, taking home $352,000 on top of his base salary, according to his contract.
In the following years, the board will evaluate his performance on goals set for him and the university to determine if his bonus will be a minimum of 10% of his base salary or a maximum of 32%.
Deferred compensation
Many universities include deferred compensation clauses in their contracts. It is money presidents can collect if they stay in their posts a certain number of years.

If Tate stays at Rutgers for five years, he will receive an additional $1.875 million in deferred compensation on top of his regular salary and bonuses, according to his contract. That is $375,000 per year of employment.
Free housing and staff
Tate and his wife, author Kim Cash Tate, will live in the nearly 100-year-old, 14,000-square-foot Rutgers president’s residence.
All of the public spaces in the Piscataway house are furnished by Rutgers and staff will be provided for cleaning, groundskeeping and maintenance.
Tate will also be provided everything he needs to have a state-of-the-art home office, according to his contract.
Rutgers is also paying all “reasonable costs” related to the Tate family’s move to New Jersey from Baton Rouge.

content_elements.caption: A view of the entrance to the Rutgers presidents' house in Piscataway, which is used for public events and as a residence for the president's family.
content_elements.subtitle: Rutgers president's house

content_elements.content: Free car and driver
Tate will receive $15,000 annually for a vehicle, his contract says. If he choses to lease a car, he could afford something similar to a new BMW SUV, which can run about $1,000 a month.
He will also have access to a university driver for Rutgers-related travel.
If Tate travels for work, his wife’s travel will also be covered by Rutgers.
Free attorney fees
If needed, the university will cover up to $20,000 in attorney’s fees “incurred by him in connection with the process related to his appointment as President,” his deal says.
Other perks
There are several other benefits listed in Tate’s contract, including:

items.content: The president is entitled to the same standard university heath and retirement benefits that all senior Rutgers faculty receive. That includes 25 days of annual vacation.

Tate can also serve on outside boards, according to his contract. He can sit on “boards, and in positions of responsibility in national and international associations related to education and other areas of public interest,” the contract says. But the appointments require approval of the Rutgers Board of Governors’ executive committee.
In addition to the title of president, Tate will be appointed as tenured faculty, gaining the titles university professor, distinguished professor and research faculty member.

content_elements.content: Though Tate’s pay is the highest-ever at the state university, he will not be the highest-paid person at Rutgers. That honor usually goes to coaches, including head football coach Greg Schiano, who earned $6.25 million last year, and head basketball coach Steve Pikiell, who took home $3.25 million, according to an NJ Advance Media analysis published last year.
It is unclear where Tate’s pay will rank among other public college presidents around the nation this year.

An analysis of 2023 college presidents’ pay by The Chronicle of Higher Education found Renu Khator, chancellor of University of Houston, was the highest paid public higher education leader that year, earning over $1.9 million in total compensation.

original.longBio:
Liz Rosenberg is the Senior Education Reporter for NJ.com, The Star-Ledger and its affiliated online newspapers. She covers New Jersey's K-12 public schools, private schools, colleges and universities. Her coverage focuses on the classroom, school finance, K-12 education policy, higher education issues and college affordability. She was named a finalist for the Education Writers Association's 2025 journalism awards for a feature on New York City school governance she wrote while working for The American Prospect magazine.

Before becoming a journalist, Rosenberg worked in public schools in New York City and Newark as a teacher and staff developer. She helped develop early college schools for the City University of New York and supported student teachers at New York University. 

As a graduate student at CUNY's Craig Newmark Graduate School, she wrote an investigation into education access at Rikers Island that was part of a series that won a Silurians Press Club merit award. 

She holds a master’s degree in journalism from City University of New York and a master's in teaching from Columbia University's Teachers College. She earned a bachelor's degree from the University of Wisconsin, Madison.

content_elements.caption: The five-lined skink prefers a moist, forested habitat.
content_elements.subtitle: Five-lined skink

content_elements.content: The five-lined skink is the only native New Jersey lizard that is found throughout the state. (Two others, the brown skink and fence lizard, are found only in the southern part of the state.)
In North America, this reptile is widespread, ranging from southern Ontario to the Gulf Coast and west to the Great Plains.
The favored habitat is a forested area with some moisture, a lot of ground cover in the form of rotten logs and woody debris, and with places in which to bask in the sun.
Old, abandoned buildings, long-established woodpiles and log dumps are suitable.

In northern New Jersey, skinks are an unexpected but not unlikely sight in rocky areas such as talus slopes, where loose boulders provide shelter and nest sites. It is unlikely to be seen in suburbia.
It’s not a big animal and it’s easy to recognize. Adults range from five to eight inches long, about half of which is tail.

The body in juveniles is dark brown to black, shiny, with five longitudinal white stripes and a blue tail, giving the species the alternate name of blue-tailed skink. The blue color and the stripes fade with age, more so in males than females.
Old males (which are rarely seen – it’s a tough world out there for a small lizard) may be uniformly brown, with a reddish-orange throat and face during breeding season.
Five-lined skinks eat insects, spiders, earthworms, amphibians including salamanders and small frogs, and occasionally smaller lizards, baby birds, and even the eggs of small birds.

Like many lizards, five-lined skinks can drop their tails when pursued by a predator. The severed tail continues to move, diverting the chase while the tailless individual escapes. The tail will regrow but will be shorter and not as flexible as the original.
These lizards are territorial, with males defending their spaces from other males but tolerating juveniles and females.
It has been suggested that the blue tail color facilitates recognition by males of these non-competitors or possible mates.

The mating season is in the springtime, and the six to 18 thin-shelled eggs are laid about one month after mating, in sheltered locations beneath rotting logs or other debris, or in rock crevices in which some organic debris has accumulated.
Freshly laid eggs are oval and about half an inch long. Incubation time varies with temperature, and can be anything from 25 to 50 days.
The females brood the eggs, defending them from small predators and maintaining moisture levels by covering them with soil or urinating on them.
The baby skinks leave the nest a few days after hatching, when they are about two inches long, and with great luck might live to be six years old.
For information about the Gloucester County Nature Club, see gcnatureclub.org/.

content_elements.subtitle: N.J. fireworks 2025 Fourth of July 4th: List of parades, concerts, events
content_elements.creditIPTC: Matt Dowling | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com

content_elements.content: The Fourth of July in 2025 falls on a Friday and sets the stage for an action packed long weekend in New Jersey of fireworks, parades, concerts and festivals to celebrate Independence Day.
There’s no shortage of July 4th festivities and if you’re making plans for a busy weekend of grilling or visiting the Jersey Shore, we’ve got you covered.
A quick reminder - while some ground-based fireworks are now legal in New Jersey, leave the big pyrotechnics to the pros.
Here’s a rundown of Fourth of July concerts, festivals, fireworks, and parades planned throughout the state.

raw_oembed.title: Ranking legal fireworks in New Jersey for July 4th
raw_oembed.html: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/BRF4jswSZks?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" referrerpolicy="strict-origin-when-cross-origin" allowfullscreen title="Ranking legal fireworks in New Jersey for July 4th"></iframe>

content_elements.content: Atlantic County

items.content: Atlantic City: Fireworks and a drone show can be viewed from the beach and boardwalk at 9 p.m. July 4, Ocean Casino Resort at The Park and at 10 p.m. July 4, Tropicana Casino and Resort.
Hammonton: Fireworks at dusk July 4, Hammonton Lake Park, 100 Sports Dr. The fireworks will be set off from the baseball field along South Egg Harbor Road.
Margate: Fireworks at 9 p.m. July 4 on the beach at Huntington Avenue. The event is hosted by the Mothers of Margate Association.

content_elements.content: Bergen County

items.content: Allendale: Independence Day Field events, 7 a.m.-noon, Recreation Park, 209-211 West Allendale Ave., with flag raising and morning salute at 7 a.m.; athletic events, including men’s horseshoe pitching contest, water balloon toss, lollipop race and ladies’ rolling pin throw, and Memorial Fun Run. Click here for details. All Star Baseball and Softball Game will be held from 1 to 4 p.m. The Allendale Holiday Observers‘ firework show will be at Crestwood Lake on July 4 from 7:30-11 p.m. The evening event will feature a concert by the Community Band of Waldwick at 7:30 p.m.

Bergen County: The county’s 2nd Annual Star Spangled Spectacular will be held on July 4. Festivities are set to begin at 2:30 p.m. in the Ridgefield Park section of Overpeck County Park. The event will include food trucks and a wine and beer garden. The New Jersey Wind Symphony will perform at 8 p.m. and the event will conclude with a fireworks display. The rain date is July 5.
Maywood: The Borough of Maywood will hold a Fireworks Celebration at Memorial Park on July 3. The rain date is July 7. Live music starts at 6:30 p.m. with fireworks set for 9:15 p.m.

Paramus: Independence Day Parade on Friday, July 4 at 9 a.m. The parade will kick off at the intersection of Farview Avenue and E. Century Road, moving north on Farview Avenue. It will culminate at the Grand Stand, located at Memorial Elementary School on Midland Avenue. The Paramus fireworks show will be Cliff Gennarelli Sports Complex on July 6. The event begins at 5 p.m.

Ridgewood: The town’s 115th Annual Fourth of July Celebration will begin Friday, July 4 with a flag raising ceremony on Wilsey Square at 9 a.m. followed by parade beginning at 10 a.m. Evening entertainment will begin at 6 p.m. with live music, food trucks, beer garden, and fireworks finale.

content_elements.content: Burlington County

items.content: Bordentown: Celebration begins at 4:30 p.m. July 3 (rain date July 6) at Joseph Lawrence Park, 316 Ward Ave. with food trucks, music, giveaways and fireworks at dusk.
Evesham: A 5k run kicks off at 8 a.m. on July 4 on Main Street. Fireworks at dusk at Savich Field, 525 East Main Street.
Medford Township: Independence Day Celebration begins at 6 p.m. July 2, at Freedom Park, 86 Union Street with food, music and fireworks at dusk.
Mount Holly: The annual Independence Day Celebration begins at 5 p.m. July 3, Iron Works Park, 157 Wollner Dr. Food, drinks, vendors. Fireworks follow at dusk.

content_elements.content: Camden County

items.content: Audubon: Independence Day parade kicks off at 8:15 a.m. on July 4 at Amherst Road and Harvard Avenue. On July 5, the fireworks pre-show beginning at 6 p.m. features food trucks, parade trophies, music and vendors followed by fireworks at 9 p.m. or dusk at Audubon High School, 350 Edgewood Ave.
Barrington: Independence Day parade at 6 p.m. July 3 with fireworks at 9:30 p.m. at Woodland School, 1 School Lane

Camden: Rock and Roll Hall of Fame inductees The Spinners will be coming to The Roland Traynor River Stage beginning at 6 p.m. July 4 with Matt Cappy & Friends and The Spinners at 8 p.m. followed by fireworks at the Freedom Festival on the Camden Waterfront, Wiggins Park, 2 Riverside Drive.
Collingswood: Fireworks can be viewed at dusk July 4 at Collingswood High School, 424 Collings Ave. Gates open 6:30 p.m.

Haddon Township: The township’s Independence Day Parade, which will step off at the municipal building at 11:30 a.m. on July 4, will end at Crystal Lake Pool. Registration will begin at 10:30 a.m. There will be prizes for best decorated bikes, wagons, trikes and floats. Free admission to the pool for the day for township residents, family and friends. There will be free hot dogs for first 300 Crystal Lake Pool Complex attendees. The pool will be open until 6 p.m.

content_elements.content: Cape May County

items.content: Avalon: The festivities in Avalon start on July 4 with a boat parade lining up at the Avalon Yacht Club at 3 p.m. Music by American Soul will run from 7 to 8:30 p.m. at Surfside Park, 29th Street, followed by fireworks on the beach at dusk.
Cape May: Fireworks go off at 9 p.m. on July 4 in front of Congress Hall.
Lower Township: An Independence Day Festival begins at 5 p.m. July 3, along the bayfront in North Cape May with rides, food and entertainment. Fireworks at 9 p.m.
Middle Township: Festivities begin at 5 p.m. July 4, Goshen Sports Complex with live music, games, food and craft vendors. Fireworks are a dusk.

Ocean City: Bike parade registration 9 a.m. July 4 with parade beginning at 10 a.m. at various locations. Kite flying competition at 7 p.m., followed by fireworks at 9 p.m. on July 4 at the 9th Street Beach.
Sea Isle City: Fireworks are scheduled for 9:15 p.m. on July 4 at the 50th Street Beach with music along portions of the promenade during the show.
Stone Harbor: A live band kicks off the evening on July 4 followed by fireworks at dusk at 81st Street and Second Avenue.
Wildwood: Celebrate Independence Day on the Wildwoods Boardwalk and watch the fireworks at 10 p.m. on July 4 from Pine Avenue and the beach.

content_elements.content: Cumberland County

items.content: Bridgeton: 9:15 p.m. on July 4 at Alden Field.
Millville: Celebration begins at 6 p.m. July 4 at Union Lake Park followed by fireworks at 9 p.m.
Vineland: Concert at 7 p.m. July 4 at Giampietro Park with fireworks at Vineland High School at 9 p.m.

content_elements.content: Essex County

items.content: Essex County: On July 2, the county is presenting a performance by The Infernos and a fireworks display will kick off at 7:30 p.m. at Essex County Brookdale Park, Watchung Avenue, Bloomfield.

Livingston: The township’s July 4th Celebration will begin at 9 a.m. on July 4 with a car show in the Livingston High School parking lot. The all-day event will feature a children’s swim carnival at the Mervyn V.T. Haines Community Pool and, at the Northland Recreation center, there will be a cricket game and pickleball tournament. On the Oval, there will be children’s activities, food trucks, vendors, an ice cream eating contest, a rolling video game truck, and a beer and wine garden with live music by Brian Drux Project and Livingston Leo & The Goodhart Boyz. The event will wind down with a performance by “Winslow – A Night with The Eagles” and fireworks on the Oval at 9 p.m. For more information, go to the township website.

Newark: Essex County Concert and Fireworks Spectacular, Tuesday, July 8 at 7:30 p.m., Essex County Weequahic Park in Newark. The concert will feature the Niche band performing Mo-Town classics and songs from the 1960s. The Fireworks Spectacular will take place after the concert.

Verona: The township is hosting its Fourth of July celebration starting at 7 p.m. on July 2. The event will feature a DJ, dancing and entertainment at Liberty Field. Fireworks will begin at approximately 9:15 p.m.

content_elements.content: Gloucester County

items.content: Washington Township: Fourth of July parade at 6:30 p.m. July 4 at Washington Township High School followed by fireworks at 9 p.m.

content_elements.content: Hunterdon County

items.content: Flemington: A fireworks display will be held in Flemington on July 3 (Rain date July 5). The event will be held at Raritan Flemington Intermediate School, 50 Court St., Fields open at 6 p.m. with fireworks set to launch at 9:15 p.m. Music and Entertainment will be provided by “Doctor D Entertainment” starting at 6:30 p.m.

Lebanon Borough: The borough will celebrate July 4 with parades and a picnic. The children’s parade (for those 10 and younger) will step off at 9:30 a.m. on Cherry Street (registration begins at 8 a.m.); the Main Parade steps off at 10 a.m., following its traditional route west on Main Street, turning onto Myrtle Avenue, then again onto Brunswick Ave, ending at Holjes-Sheppard Memorial Park. The borough’s annual picnic begins immediately after the parade ends.

content_elements.content: Hudson County

items.content: Bayonne: The city’s Independence Day Celebration will be held on July 2, at the lower level of DiDomenico-16th Street Park, beginning at 6:30 p.m., weather permitting. The rain date is July 3. The event will feature children’s activities until 8:30 p.m., with rides stationed in the old amphitheater. “The Suspects” band will perform at 7 p.m. Fireworks are scheduled to go off at approximately 9:15 p.m. Food vendors will be located in the parking lot. For more information, go to the county website.

Jersey City: The 2025 Fourth of July Festival and Fireworks Spectacular will take place along the Jersey City waterfront on July 4. The celebration kicks off at noon at Exchange Place and will feature more than 60 vendors, 3 DJ stages, two beer gardens and a Kids’ Zone with activations and bounce castles. The festivities will conclude with a fireworks display by Fireworks by Grucci over the Hudson River.

content_elements.content: Mercer County

items.content: East Windsor: The township will hold its fireworks show at dusk on July 5 at Etra Lake Park.

Trenton: The Mercer County Improvement Authority will host a 4th of July extravaganza at Trenton Thunder Ballpark on July 4 starting at 6 p.m. The event will feature an Uncle Sam Great American Picnic,

content_elements.content: Middlesex County

items.content: East Brunswick: The township is holding a fireworks spectacular on July 4 starting at 6 p.m. The rain date is July 5. The event will be held at the Community Arts Center, 721 Cranbury Road. The event will feature food trucks, a DJ, a performance from the East Brunswick Symphony Orchestra and children’s entertainers.

Edison Township’s Fourth of July celebration will start at 5:40 p.m. on July 4. There will be music by Larger Than Life and the B Street Band. The event, to be held in  Papaianni Park, will include a kids zone and beer and wine garden.

Helmetta: Helmetta Spark in the Park fireworks on July 3 at Helmetta Lake Park. The celebration, featuring music, food trucks and children’s entertainment, will start at Fireworks will start at 6 p.m. Rain date July 6.

Milltown: The town will host a fireworks display on at 9 p.m. on July 4 in Gloria Bradford Park. The town’s Fourth of July festivities also include a fishing derby, 5k race, parade, duck race, pizza eating contest, patriotic house contest, bike contest, and music.
Perth Amboy: The city will celebrate the Fourth of July from 4-9:30 p.m. on July 2; fireworks start at 9:20 p.m. The rain date is July 3.

Piscataway: “A Revolutionary Celebration: Independence Day on the Raritan“, July 4, 8:30 a.m.-4 p.m., East Jersey Old Town Village, 1050 River Road. Commemorate the 1778 feu de joie ordered by Gen. George Washington Revolutionary War-era reenactments, 18th-century music, storytelling, and patriotic festivities. The day begins with a Revolutionary Celebration Run and continues with food vendors, historic interpretations, and performances on the Village lawn.
Woodbridge: The townshp will have its celebration on July 3 with gates opening at 4 p.m. at Alvin P. Williams Memorial Park, Sewaren. AM Gold will perform. Rain date is July 5.

content_elements.content: Monmouth County

items.content: Asbury Park: Fireworks on July 3 at Asbury Boardwalk & Beach. Rain date is July 5.
Atlantic Highlands: Fireworks on July 3 at the Marina at 9:45 p.m.. Rain date is July 5.
Belmar: 4th of July Fireworks & Light Show, July 5, 8 p.m., Taylor Pavilion, 500 Ocean Ave N.
Bradley Beach: Fireworks on July 5 at the Beach Front. Fireworks begin at dusk. Rain date is July 6.
Hazlet Township: Fireworks on July 3 at Veterans’ Park, 1776 Union Ave. With music and food trucks, the celebration starts at 6 p.m. Rain date is July 6.
Long Branch: Oceanfest 4th of July celebration with fireworks, live entertainment and food trucks on July 4.
Manasquan: Parade, beach concert and fireworks, on July 3 from 5:15-10 p.m.
Keansburg: The city’s Amusement Park & Runaway Rapids is holding a fireworks show July 3 at 9 p.m.

content_elements.content: Morris County

items.content: Dover: Independence Day Fireworks Celebration on July 3. Gates open at 6 p.m. the event will be held at Hamilton Field, 302 E. McFarlan St.
Randolph Township: 49th Annual Freedom Festival, July 12, 9:45 p.m., County College of Morris, Lot 1, 214 Center Grove Road.

content_elements.content: Ocean County

items.content: Barnegat Township: Celebration begins at 5 p.m. July 5 with food trucks and music followed by fireworks at dusk at Barnegat High School.

Beach Haven Fourth of July Fireworks presented by @fantasyislandlbi and The Beach Haven Chamber of Commerce will be held at 9:30 p.m. on July 4, at Taylor Park. Bay Village will host fireworks on Taylor Avenue at dusk.

Lakewood: The Jersey Shore BlueClaws are hosting a special “Red, White & BlueClaws” celebration with fireworks at the end of the game July 3 when the BlueClaws face off against the Wilmington Blue Rocks at 7:05 p.m.

Lakewood Township Independence Day Celebration will be held on Monday, July 7 from 8 to 9:15 p.m. The event will include live music and fireworks at North Lake Park, overlooking Lake Carasaljo. The Wilbur Wittemann Patriotic Band will conduct a special musical performance at the park’s All Wars Memorial Amphitheater, followed by a live fireworks show that can be viewed from both North Lake Drive and South Lake Drive.
Lavallette: Fireworks at 9 p.m. July 6 at the Centennial Gardens and Gazebo.
Seaside Heights: Fireworks at 9:30 p.m. July 6 on the boardwalk.

content_elements.content: Passaic County

items.content: Clifton: The City of Clifton will host its annual Independence Day Celebration on Sunday, July 6, in- and outside Clifton Stadium located at 350 Piaget Ave. This year —for the first time in more than 50 years, the Independence Day Celebration will include a carnival. Featuring live entertainment, food, fireworks, and more. In the event of inclement weather, the celebration will be held on Monday, July 7.

content_elements.content: Salem County

items.content: Woodstown-Pilesgrove: Fireworks at dusk on July 4 at Marlton Park, 123 Marlton Road, Pilesgrove.

content_elements.content: Somerset County

items.content: Bridgewater: The Somerset Patriots are planning two nights of fireworks on July 4 and 5 at TD Bank Ballpark following games against the Reading Fightin Phils. Both games start at 7:05 p.m.

Bridgewater: Somerset County will have fireworks at North Branch Park in Bridgewater on July 4 at 9:30 p.m. Yacht Rock Gold Experience will perform from 8:30-9:30 p.m. and 10-11 p.m. The N.J. 3rd Regiment Revolutionary War encampment will be onsite. Food trucks will be available.
Franklin Township: Fireworks on July 3 from at 9:15 p.m. Entertainment and food will be featured from 6-9 p.m. at the Franklin Municipal Township complex, 475 DeMott Lane..

content_elements.content: Sussex County

items.content: Frankford: The Sussex County Miners will have fireworks at Skylands Stadium, 94 Championship Place, Augusta, on July 4 and July 5. Gates open at 4:30 p.m. The Miners will be taking on the Ottawa Titans.

Vernon: Mountain Creek Resort will host a July 4th Fireworks Celebration on on July 4, starting at 5 p.m. The resort, located at 200 Route 94, will present an evening to include food, a beer garden, local vendors, live music, children’s activities and games such as corn hole and giant pong on the Great Lawn outside of Red Tail Lodge. The evening will be highlighted by a fireworks display. Upon arrival, the participating Vernon Fire Departments, representing Vernon, McAfee, Highland Lakes, and Pochuck Valley, will be collecting a $20 parking fee per car, in which 100% of the proceeds will go to volunteer organizations. For more information and to purchase parking in advance, visit the resort website.

content_elements.content: Union County

items.content: Elizabeth: The city’s celebration will be held on July 4 at Veteran’s Memorial Waterfront Park, Elizabeth Avenue and Front Street. The event, which will begin at 2 p.m.,  will feature food trucks, music and other entertainment throughout the day. Fireworks will go off at dusk. The rain date is July 5.

New Providence: Independence Day Celebration will be held on July 3 at 7 p.m. The downtown celebration will include music and sidewalk chalk. Fireworks will go off at 9:15 p.m. and should be visible from most locations in town. Residents are encouraged to set up lawn chairs and “settle into a favorite viewing spot.”

Summit: Celebration from noon to 10 p.m. on July 4. The event, which will be held at Soldiers Memorial Field, 5 Myrtle Ave., will feature a flag raising ceremony, amusement rides, food trucks, a children’s decorated bicycle parade, music, and, of course fireworks.

Union Township: Free Fourth of July concert featuring the Misson Dance at 7:30 p.m. on July 4, with fireworks to follow.; the rain date is July 5 for the event, which will be held at Biertuempfel Park.

content_elements.content: Warren County

items.content: Blairstown: The Blairstown Rotary will have fireworks at North Warren Regional High School on July 3 the fireworks will begin at 9 p.m.

content_elements.caption: Dylan Harper poses for a photo with NBA commissioner Adam Silver after being selected second by the San Antonio Spurs In the first round of the NBA basketball draft, Wednesday, June 25, 2025, in New York. (AP Photo/Adam Hunger)
content_elements.subtitle: NBA Draft Basketball

content_elements.content: The Oklahoma City Thunder just won the NBA championship with a “Big 3″ of Shai Gilgeous-Alexander, Jalen Williams and Chet Holmgren.
Two of the three -- Williams and Holmgren -- were drafted by the Thunder, and all three are considered the core of a team that could win multiple rings in the coming years.
The San Antonio Spurs hope to take a page out of Oklahoma City’s book with a young “Big 3″ of their own -- and that trio features Victor Wembanyama, Steph Castle and ex-Rutgers star Dylan Harper.

Wembanyama and Castle are the last two Rookies of the Year in the league, and Harper could contend for the award next season along with No. 1 overall pick Cooper Flagg of the Dallas Mavericks and former Rutgers teammate Ace Bailey, the No. 5 pick of the Utah Jazz, among others.
“The Spurs think that this could be their trio that they drafted in a row, Victor Wembanyama, then Stephon Castle, now Dylan Harper,” ESPN’s Brian Windhorst said Tuesday night on air.

“They backed it up with some other veterans that they brought in around them, but this is what they’re excited about. And if you look at what’s happened in Dallas, just up the road in Texas, look at Cooper Flagg. These three teams are all drafting and all trying to build the same way [as] their Southwest Division rivals [the Thunder] as well.”
ESPN’s Paul Biancardi praised Harper -- who set a Rutgers freshman scoring record with 564 points last season -- as a “bigger, stronger’ version of Knicks’ All-Star point guard Jalen Brunson.

“Dylan Harper plays like a bigger, stronger Jalen Brunson,” Biancardi told NJ Advance Media. “He navigates the ball screen with scoring ability and a keen understanding of reading the coverage and help defense.
“He plays effectively off two feet as he approaches the basket, finds the open pocket of space for his mid-range shot, and knows when to accelerate and decelerate.”
Before being drafted No. 2 overall by the Spurs, Harper appeared on SportsCenter and talked about what it would be like to join Wembanyama, Castle, De’Aaron Fox and the Spurs.

“I mean, that would definitely be great and I would definitely be blessed to have that opportunity just because they’re two young players, young stars, and the rest of the team from top to bottom is really good so when you get to play with better players and the best of the best, it just brings out your best game,” Harper said.
The Spurs are +700 to win the Southwest division next season on DraftKings. Our complete DraftKings Sportsbook review shows you how to sign up and use their platform.

Former NBA player Tim Legler believes the Spurs have a young nucleus capable of challenging for a spot in the Play-In Tournament this year, and doing some real damage in the rugged Western Conference in years to come.
“This team could potentially be in the mix for the Play-In if everybody stays healthy,” he said. “This season.”
Thank you for relying on us to provide the journalism you can trust. Please consider supporting us with a subscription.
Adam Zagoria is a freelance reporter and Basketball Insider for NJ Advance Media. You may follow him on Twitter @AdamZagoria and check out his Website at ZAGSBLOG.com.

original.byline: Adam Zagoria | For NJ Advance Media
original.longBio:
Adam Zagoria is a Basketball Insider who covers hoops at all levels -- NBA, College and Recruiting. For NJ.com, he has written about how projected No. 1 NBA Draft pick Cooper Flagg wasn’t born a basketball star. In fact, the nation’s top prospect was lucky to have been born at all. He covered former Seton Hall star isaiah Whitehead's harrowing escape from Israel after the Oct. 7 Hamas attack caused Whitehead to hear missiles and  bombs going off. And he has written about how an army of NBA scouts are expected this season for Rutgers' freshmen Ace Bailey and Dylan Harper.

In his free time, Adam has played in the National and World Championships in Ultimate Frisbee, and has seen more rock concerts than he cares to count.

He is the author of two books and is an award-winning filmmaker.

content_elements.caption: Shooters take aim from the deck of the Battleship New Jersey during the First Annual Sporting Clay Invitational on June 26 on the Camden Waterfront.
content_elements.subtitle: Battleship New Jersey First Annual Sporting Clay Invitational

content_elements.content: The Battleship New Jersey became a floating shooting range as dozens of competitors fired at clay targets soaring over the Delaware River last week.
Shot after shot rang out from the deck of the historic ship on the Camden waterfront Thursday as competitors shattered thousands of discs during an unconventional fundraising event.
For the first time, the Battleship New Jersey Museum and Memorial hosted a clay shooting competition aboard the nation’s most decorated and fastest Navy warship.
The idea took shape earlier this year as museum leaders searched for new ways to raise money following state funding cuts.

items.content: MORE: Battleship New Jersey gets a hero’s welcome in return to N.J. after $10M makeover

content_elements.content: “We wanted to create something bold, memorable, and completely unique to the Battleship,” Marshall Spevak, CEO of the Battleship New Jersey said in a statement. “There’s nothing else like it in the country — shooting clays from the deck of a battleship while supporting a living piece of American history.”

What began as a single concept — one shooting station and a single trap machine — quickly expanded. After a few planning meetings, organizers decided to close the ship to the public for the day and go all in.

content_elements.caption: Trap machines launch biodegradable clay targets over the Delaware River during the Battleship New Jersey’s Sporting Clay Invitational on June 26 in Camden.
content_elements.subtitle: Battleship New Jersey First Annual Sporting Clay Invitational

content_elements.content: “After the third meeting, they said, ‘We’re going to close the ship down for this event. How can we get the most shooting possible?’” said Joe Pancoast, owner of Cedar Creek Sporting Clays.
The fundraising event was held in partnership with Cedar Creek Sporting Clays, a professional shooting course based in Cumberland County that specializes in sporting clay events.

Eighty competitors, from seasoned sportsmen and enthusiasts to military veterans, packed the ship’s deck by midday. Divided into 20 teams, they cycled through eight shooting stations as 12 trap machines launched more than 5,000 clay targets into the sky.
To ensure the event was environmentally safe, shooters used shotgun shells loaded with steel shot and paper wads.
“Everything that went into the river was biodegradable,” Pancoast said.

content_elements.caption: Shooters take aim from the deck of the Battleship New Jersey during the First Annual Sporting Clay Invitational on June 26 on the Camden Waterfront.
content_elements.subtitle: Battleship New Jersey First Annual Sporting Clay Invitational

content_elements.content: The top team walked away with a custom-made trophy crafted from the ship’s decking.
The competition was held aboard the newly repaired and freshly painted Battleship New Jersey, which returned to its home dock in Camden last year following a 12-week, $10 million restoration project.
Known as “Big J,” the USS New Jersey is the most decorated, fastest and longest battleship in Navy history.

It was commissioned in 1942 and served in World War II, the Korean War, the Vietnam War and the Cold War before being decommissioned in 1991. Since 2001, it has been operating as a museum on the Camden waterfront.
Participants called the shooting event unlike anything the ship has ever hosted — a rare opportunity for both shooters and spectators that could now become an annual event.
“It was a day of competition, connection, and community — and we look forward to making this an annual tradition," Spevak said.

content_elements.caption: Shooters take aim from the deck of the Battleship New Jersey during the First Annual Sporting Clay Invitational on June 26 on the Camden Waterfront.
content_elements.subtitle: Battleship New Jersey First Annual Sporting Clay Invitational

content_elements.caption: The National Weather Service forecast for Wednesday includes more rain and scattered thunderstorms across the southern half of New Jersey. On Thursday, afternoon and evening thunderstorms are possible in the northern half of the state.
content_elements.subtitle: N.J. weather: Forecast for today, Thursday includes more rain, thunderstorms

content_elements.content: Scattered showers and isolated thunderstorms are in the forecast for most of New Jersey today followed by another round of afternoon thunderstorms Thursday.
But once the storms are done, the Fourth of July weekend forecast looks promising.
Scattered light rain and thunderstorms are possible through midday today, primarily for the southern half of New Jersey.
“We will have a split forecast today across the region,” the National Weather Service said.

“North and west of the I-95 corridor will be cloudy to start, but drier, sunnier, and warmer by the afternoon with highs in the upper 80s,” the weather service said “South and east, we will still see lingering showers and a few thunderstorms through the morning and into the early afternoon, leading to more clouds and cooler temperatures with highs in the low 80s.”

content_elements.caption: The National Weather Service forecast for Wednesday includes more rain and scattered thunderstorms across the southern half of New Jersey. On Thursday, afternoon and evening thunderstorms are possible in the northern half of the state.
content_elements.subtitle: N.J. weather: Forecast for today, Thursday includes more rain, thunderstorms

content_elements.content: High humidity will persist until the front moves offshore. Any afternoon thunderstorms may produce heavy downpours but are not expected to become severe.
By Thursday, another cold front will cross the region, potentially triggering isolated thunderstorms, mainly northwest of I-95.
These storms could produce localized damaging wind gusts and small hail. Temperatures will remain in the mid to upper 80s, with humidity levels dropping significantly.
The Fourth of July forecast looks ideal, with sunny skies and temperatures in the low to mid 80s.
Both Friday and Saturday will continue the pleasant weather pattern, featuring dry conditions and comfortable temperatures.
By Sunday, temperatures will climb to near 90 degrees with increasing humidity.
Early next week, more unsettled weather is expected, with daily chances of showers and thunderstorms and temperatures potentially reaching near 90 degrees.
Rip current risks remain moderate today, with breaking wave heights of 1-3 feet along the New Jersey coastline.

content_elements.caption: Democratic nominee Mikie Sherrill (left) and Republican nominee Jack Ciattarelli (right) celebrate their primary wins. They will now face each other in November in the general election to become New Jersey's next governor.
content_elements.subtitle: Sherrill Ciattarelli new

content_elements.content: Democrat Mikie Sherrill leads Republican Jack Ciattarelli by 20 percentage points in the first major general-election poll in New Jersey’s big governor’s race, released about four months to Election Day.

The Rutgers-Eagleton Poll, out Wednesday, found President Donald Trump looms heavily as voters pick a new governor to succeed term-limited Democratic Gov. Phil Murphy. But the gap between the two nominees narrows on economic issues and 1-in-5 independent voters are undecided, according to the survey.
The poll shows 51% of Jerseyans would pick Sherrill, a U.S. congresswoman, if the Nov. 4 election were today.
That’s compared to 31% who’d back Ciattarelli, a former member of the state Assembly and the GOP nominee who lost to Murphy by a narrow margin in a closer-than-expected race four years ago.
When residents who lean toward a candidate are added, Sherrill leads Ciattarelli 56% to 35%.
Meanwhile, 5% say they support neither candidate or someone else and 13% are unsure.
The survey was conducted a few days after Sherrill and Ciattarelli emerged with their parties’ nominations in the June 10 primary.
The figures paint a wider gap between Sherrill and Ciattarelli than many political insiders and experts have been expecting.

Ashley Koning, director of the Eagleton Center for Public Interest Polling at Rutgers University-New Brunswick, said in a statement that “early polling on the governor’s race should serve as a baseline or a barometer of how voters are feeling in the moment — not as some crystal ball predicting the future four months from now."

“A lot can happen between now and November, and we know this gap will very likely narrow in the next several months,” Koning added. “We only need to look back to 2021 to see how much a race can change throughout a cycle. Add to this an intense national political landscape that will, once again, surely play a role in the governor’s race here at home. Come November, what will matter is who actually turns out to vote.”
For reference, a Rutgers-Eagleton poll just before the 2021 primaries showed Murphy leading Ciattarelli by 26 points. Murphy ended up beating him by about 3.

The poll shows 52% of residents say Trump is a “major factor” in their vote, 18% say he’s a “minor” one, and 30% say he isn’t one at all. Sherrill supporters are more likely to say the Republican president is a major factor, while 48% of independents say the same.

Trump endorsed Ciattarelli, a former critic, in the GOP primary. Sherrill has repeatedly tied him to the president in a blue-leaning state where registered Democratic voters outnumber registered Republicans by about 800,000, though Trump reduced his margin of loss in the state last year.

“Trump’s influence appears to be more of a benefit to Sherrill right now, given key groups more likely to support her are also more likely to claim the president is a factor in their vote choice, while those more supportive of Ciattarelli do not,” Koning said. “While Trump’s endorsement may have helped in the primaries, these numbers are an early sign that the endorsement may play differently when it comes to the general.”
The poll shows Jerseyans are split on who would better handle taxes: 39% say Sherrill, 34% Ciattarelli, 14% neither, and 14% unsure.
On who’s better to handle cost of living and affordability, 45% say Sherrill, 29% Ciattarelli, 13% neither, and 13% are uncertain.
As for other big issues:

items.content: On economy and jobs, Ciattarelli leads 42% to 33%.
On state budget and government spending, Ciattarelli leads 42% to 32%.
On health care, Sherrill leads 51% to 24%.
On education and schools, Sherrill leads 50% to 24%
On transportation and infrastructure, Sherrill leads 45% to 29%.
On crime and safety, Sherrill leads 39% to 37%.

content_elements.content: Democrats and Republicans tend to side with their nominees on those issues, but it’s a toss-up for independents on the economy, taxes, cost of living and affordability, and crime and safety. Sherrill leads with independents on education and schools (46% to 19%), health care (45% to 16%), and transportation and infrastructure (40% to 23%).

Ciattarelli strategist Chris Russell sharply criticized the survey on social media, calling it a “steaming pile of s**t.” He argued the methodology over-represented Murphy and Kamala Harris and Murphy supporters.
Koning, the poll’s director, pushed back.

“Our scientifically grounded methodology follows best practices in the survey research industry,” she said in a statement. “Polls are still the most reliable, systematic, and scientific tool for assessing public opinion.”
The poll also found:

items.content: Both Sherrill and Ciattarelli saw jumps in name ID since April. For Sherrill, 50% now see her favorably (up 30 points), while 21% view her unfavorably (up 7 points), 17% have no opinion (down 5 points), and 12% don’t know her (down 32 points). For Ciattarelli, 33% now view him favorably (up 15 points), though 42% see him unfavorably (up 18 points), 15% have no opinion (down 11 points), and 9% don’t know him (down 23 points).

Sherrill’s base has more quickly consolidated, with 89% of Democrats saying they’d vote for her. On the other side, 74% of Republicans would vote for Ciattarelli. Twice as many Republicans (14%) as Democrats (7%) are uncertain. Independents are more likely to go for Sherrill (45%) over Ciattarelli (28%), though 20% are undecided.

There’s an equal amount of enthusiasm among both candidates’ supporters, with 78% of Sherrill backers saying they’re “very” (30%) or “somewhat” (48%) enthusiastic about the Democrat, compared to 80% of Ciattarelli supporters saying they’re “very” (29%) or “somewhat” (51%) enthusiastic about the Republian.
Sherrill is seen as the more moderate candidate, with 25% saying she’s moderate, 35% “somewhat liberal,” and 16% “very liberal.
Ciattarelli is viewed as more conservative, with 34% saying he’s “very conservative,” 34% “somewhat conservative,” and 10% “moderate.”
78% of residents say they’ll definitely vote in November, while 15% say probably.

content_elements.content: The statewide poll was conducted via phone with 621 New Jersey adults — including 579 registered voters — from June 13-16. The margin of error was plus-or-minus 5.4 percentage points.

content_elements.content: Asbury Park is awesome. But is it already over?

This week, Jersey’s Best Podcast is analyzing the cultural crown jewel of the Jersey Shore — Asbury Park. It has a checkered past, a conflicting present and an unclear future. Has the city’s resurgence gone too far, or is the best yet to come?

The latest episode is out now on Spotify, Apple Podcasts and wherever you get your podcasts. Check it out (plus all the previous episodes, as well). If you like what you hear, please subscribe and leave us a review.

In case you missed the announcement, this weekly podcast is hosted by me, NJ.com food and culture reporter Jeremy Schneider. Joining me will be a cast of very Jersey guests as we break down all the things that make the Garden State spectacular, bizarre, sometimes annoying, but always the best.
More on our latest episode: Has Asbury Park Already Peaked? A Deep Dive into Jersey’s Hottest Shore Town.

raw_oembed.title: Has Asbury Park Already Peaked? A Deep Dive into Jersey's Hottest Shore Town| Jersey's Best Podcast
raw_oembed.html: <iframe width="560" height="315" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/Fy9mAmtp1LQ?feature=oembed" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" referrerpolicy="strict-origin-when-cross-origin" allowfullscreen title="Has Asbury Park Already Peaked? A Deep Dive into Jersey's Hottest Shore Town| Jersey's Best Podcast"></iframe>

content_elements.content: Here’s something new! Welcome to a new series dedicated to New Jersey’s cities and towns — taking a closer look at the culture and history of these beloved places and analyzing why they matter so much to the Garden State at large. First up: Asbury Park, an iconic shore town with a checkered past, a conflicting present and an unclear future. In the 2000s, Asbury Park became the epicenter of a cultural revival. Twenty years later, gentrification and corporate influences have led to constant construction, an overabundance of high-rise apartments and absolute chaos on beach days. Yes, Asbury Park was reborn. But is its cultural renaissance already over? Host Jeremy Schneider is joined by Phil Fazio, a longtime city resident and veteran of Asbury Park’s dining industry. Listen as the guys dive into the city’s history, whether it has already peaked, the evolution of an iconic music club and which Jersey Shore town will be the next Asbury Park.
PREVIOUS EPISODES:
Episode 1: Jersey’s Most Breathtakingly Ugly Places, Ranked!
Episode 2: Wawa vs. QuickChek: The Ultimate Showdown — With Taste Test!
Episode 3: Jersey’s Best Animals, And Which Could Beat Jeremy In A Fight
Episode 4: Jersey’s Best Slang — Why Do We Talk Like This?
Episode 5: Crowning The Best And Worst Turnpike Exits — It’s The Roadie Awards!
Bonus episode: All 13 Roller Coasters at Six Flags Great Adventure, Ranked!
Episode 6: The Great New Jersey Food Debate — with Pete Genovese!
Episode 7: What North Jersey Doesn’t Get About South Jersey
Episode 8: Our Deepest, Darkest Jersey Confessions Revealed!
Episode 9: Jersey’s Best Celebrities: The Ultimate Tier List!
Episode 10: Jersey’s 9 Circles of Hell!
Episode 11: The 10 worst people you’ll meet at the Jersey Shore this summer
Episode 12: Why Jersey bagels matter: The culture, the craft and the hole truth
Episode 13: All 45 Jersey Shore Beaches, Ranked Worst to Best — SPEED RUN!
Episode 14: N.J.’s 10 most embarrassing moments, ranked. A very cringy history.
Our journalism needs your support. Please subscribe today to NJ.com.
Jeremy Schneider may be reached at jschneider@njadvancemedia.com and followed on Twitter at @J_Schneider and on Instagram at @JeremyIsHungryAgain.

He won a Society for Features Journalism award for his feature on Santillo's Brick Oven Pizza in 2020, and his food writing portfolio earned him an honorable mention in 2022. original.bio: Joey Chandler is a pro and college sports reporter at NJ.com with a primary focus on sports commerce. You can also find her at Jersey Mike's Arena covering the Rutgers women's basketball team. Her work has won awards at national and state levels.
original.longBio: Joey Chandler is a pro and college sports commerce reporter at NJ.com. You can also find her at Jersey Mike's Arena covering the Rutgers women's basketball team. Chandler is in her 19th year as a sports journalist. Her work has been recognized at national and state levels. She's earned Associated Press Sports Editors honors and won first-place writing awards for features, columns and breaking news in Ohio, Alabama and North Carolina. She joined NJ.com in late April of 2021. Before arriving in New Jersey, she covered East Carolina University athletics for the Wilmington StarNews. She spent five years at the Tuscaloosa News as a preps writer, assisting with Alabama football coverage and the sports department intern program. In 2015, she was selected to take part in the APSE Diversity Fellowship program. She started her career covering high school sports in Ohio, including stops with the Mount Vernon News, Chillicothe Gazette and Bucyrus Telegraph-Forum. She graduated from Ashland University in Ashland, Ohio in 2006, majoring in sport communication and journalism.

content_elements.caption: The July 4th, 2025, holiday is on Friday this year. Several stores and services will be open, but some will be closed in observance of the holiday.

by.byline: John Jones | For NJ Advance Medi
by.name: John Jones | For NJ Advance Medi

content_elements.subtitle: July 4th, 2025

content_elements.content: The July 4th, 2025 holiday falls on Friday this year.
It’s an American holiday that became a tradition in the 18th century during the American Revolution.

On July 4, 1776, delegates from the 13 colonies adopted the Declaration of Independence, a historic document drafted by Thomas Jefferson, after the Continental Congress voted in favor of independence.
Today, people often celebrate the holiday by attending barbecues, parades, festivals, fairs or going to fireworks displays.
In New Jersey, some cities and towns, such as Atlantic City and Beach Haven, have their fireworks on July 4.
Here is everything to know about what’s open and what’s closed on 4th of July 2025.
Is the 4th of July a federal holiday?
Yes, the 4th of July is the sixth federal and state holiday of the year.
Is the post office open on 4th of July 2025?
No, the United States Postal Service will not be open on Friday, July 4.
Does the mail run on 4th of July 2025? Is there mail delivery?
There will be no regular mail delivery on Friday, July 4th.
FedEx, Amazon and UPS also will not deliver mail on Friday, July 4, except for FedEx Custom Critical and UPS Express Critical.
FedEx Office will also have modified hours while UPS Express Critical service will also be available.
Are banks open on 4th of July 2025?
Many in-person and drive-thru services will be closed on Friday.
The following banks are scheduled to be closed on the 4th of July:

items.content: Bank of America
Capital One Bank
Chase
Citibank
Citizens Bank
PNC Bank
Santander Bank
TD Bank
Truist Bank
Wells Fargo

Shoppers should ultimately check with their local supermarket for specific information on opening and closing hours, as it can vary by location.

content_elements.content: What gas stations are open on 4th of July 2025?
Most gas stations in New Jersey, with few exceptions, will be open and ready to serve you on 4th of July 2025.
Major chains and convenience stores are more likely to have their pumps open on the holiday, although they might be operating at reduced hours.
Independent gas stations, on the other hand, may choose to close on the 4th of July holiday.
Regardless of where you choose to fill up, it is important to check the hours of operation of the gas station as hours may vary by location.
The following gas stations are open on 4th of July 2025:

content_elements.content: Is the stock market closed on July 4th, 2025?
The New York Stock Exchange will be closed on Friday, July 4. It will also close early on Thursday, July 3, at 1 p.m.
Nasdaq trading and bond markets also will be closed.
Does NJ Transit, PATH and SEPTA operate on a normal schedule on 4th of July 2025?
NJ Transit will observe the 4th of July holiday on Friday, July 4.
Buses will run on either a Saturday or Sunday service, and some lines will not run on the holiday. Trains will run weekend/major holiday schedule on all lines.

Hudson-Bergen Light Rail will operate on a weekend/holiday schedule until 10 a.m. After 10 a.m., it will run on a modified schedule. Newark Light Rail will run on a Saturday schedule while the River Line will operate on a Sunday/holiday schedule.
Riders should use NJ Transit’s online trip planner to double-check arrival and departure times.
PATH will operate on a modified Saturday schedule on July 4, while the Journal Square-33 Street (via Hoboken) and Newark-World Trade Center lines will still be operating.
SEPTA will operate on its Sunday schedule on July 4, except bus routes 204, 310, 311 and LUCY that don’t operate on Sunday service. SEPTA will also have additional midday and late night rail service.
Are New Jersey Motor Vehicle Commission locations open on 4th of July 2025?
All Motor Vehicle Commission locations will be closed on Friday, July 4 to observe the 4th of July holiday.
Additionally, all New Jersey state offices and courts will be closed.
When is the next federal holiday?
The next federal holiday is Labor Day on Monday, Sept. 1, 2025.
For more information about the history of the 4th of July, check out the video below:

content_elements.caption: July 2 birthday horoscope and your daily astrology
content_elements.subtitle: July 2 birthday horoscope and your daily astrology

content_elements.content: IF JULY 2 IS YOUR BIRTHDAY: In a couple of weeks, you may have a prime window for seizing opportunities, making key decisions, and gaining recognition, as your sound judgment and long-range vision are likely at their peak. Consider launching major ventures for a good chance at success. Social events may fill your calendar, and while you might be busier than usual, group activities and networking could reveal unexpected rewards. In August, tread carefully—an impulsive choice could disrupt your peace of mind. The latter half of September is ideal for rest, though a few days may financial decisions or new investments. Be cautious not to overlook details or fall for strategies designed to drain your resources. Your leadership and enthusiasm may shine in early October but resist the urge to make sudden changes. By late October, your romantic energy is strong—a weekend getaway could bring your dreams to life.

CANCER (June 21-July 22): Some people only learn the hard way and may ignore advice. Those you’re dealing with may be set in their ways or act unpredictably, patience will be key. Notice if a few of your own choices don’t align with sound judgment, either.

LEO (July 23-Aug. 22): Trust your instincts and stay alert. Consider when to follow the rules and when to forge your own path. Quick thinking can help you sidestep potential problems. Avoid risky moves, even if ideas seem exciting or you’re eager to please someone.

VIRGO (Aug. 23-Sept. 22): Clear up rumors or doubts by addressing them directly. Ignoring misunderstandings or brushing issues aside could lead to still more confusion. Caution is your best ally, someone’s hidden agenda may be working against your own.

LIBRA (Sept. 23-Oct. 22): Looking toward the weekend, social events with fun-loving people may be on your mind. Business strategies and financial planning might take up much of your time, but you may still want to find space for romance.

SCORPIO (Oct. 23-Nov. 21): Impulsive decisions may have worked for you in the past, but circumstances may have shifted. Now, deeper research is likely needed to achieve similar success. Things will improve even more once you fully understand how everything works.

SAGITTARIUS (Nov. 22-Dec. 21): If you feel grouped into a stereotype, think about ways to stand out. On the flip side, someone close to you—possibly through work—could surprise you by being refreshingly authentic, original, and a true nonconformist.

CAPRICORN (Dec. 22-Jan. 19): You may hesitate to support a cause due to a packed schedule. Hold off on launching new projects or fundraising efforts until the timing feels right. A family member or colleague could disrupt your plans with unexpected actions or words.

AQUARIUS (Jan. 20-Feb. 18): Ideas may begin to dawn after a night, or a few nights, of mental fog. If you feel ready to act on your thoughts, start moving toward your goals. Take full advantage of today’s mental clarity to assess and firm up plans.

PISCES (Feb. 19-March 20): Be mindful of your limits, especially when it comes to money. Without discipline, you could overspend or agree to something you might regret. Dream big but focus on goals that are within reach. Don’t let small frustrations lead to overreactions.

ARIES (March 21-April 19): You might feel sharper than those around you, but this attitude may not sit well with family members. Your worldly insight may make you an expert in some areas, but it won’t necessarily help you build harmony at home.

TAURUS (April 20-May 20): Something new or unexpected may catch your attention or tempt you to slack off today. Disconnect from social media and emails until your tasks are complete. Save social time for later to stay focused and productive.

GEMINI (May 21-June 20): Keep your spending in check, as quality items or real bargains may be hard to find. It might be tempting to buy something just to feel like you’re getting a deal. You could feel financially stretched or limited by your current budget.

BIRTHDAY STAR: Actor Nelson Franklin was born in Montreal, Quebec, Canada, on this date in 1985. This birthday star portrayed Connor Stevens on “Black-ish” from 2016 - 2020. He also played Will on “Veep,” and he’s appeared on episodes of “Yellowjackets,” “A Man on the Inside,” and “Mr. Throwback.” On the big screen, Franklin’s film resume includes roles in “Being the Ricardos,” “Have a Good Trip,” and “A Futile and Stupid Gesture.”

headlines.basic: The Newark Anti-Violence Coalition marches to condemn gun violence

content_elements.caption: File photo: Members of the community attend a march in Newark on Thursday, July 21, 2022, organized by the Newark Anti-Violence Coalition to condemn shootings. Community-based violence intervention programs are at risk because of federal funding cuts, experts say.

affiliation.name: Julian Leshay | For NJ Advance M

by.byline: Julian Leshay | For NJ Advance Media
by.name: Julian Leshay | For NJ Advance Media

content_elements.subtitle: The Newark Anti-Violence Coalition
content_elements.creditIPTC: Julian Leshay | For NJ Advance M

content_elements.content: Editor’s note: This story was originally published byNJ Spotlight News and shared as part of a content-sharing agreement between Mosaic.NJ.com and NJ Spotlight News. You can follow them on Facebook and Twitter (or X).
Community-based violence intervention programs are a key component in reducing and preventing gun violence across the state, advocates, academics and state officials say.

No statewide data points to a direct correlation between a reduction in homicide rates and the work of these programs. But recent data from the state shows the programs have contributed significantly to a reduction in the number of people who were shot across New Jersey.

In 2023, 924 people were shot in the state, a 13% reduction compared to 2022, according to a recent report from the attorney general’s office. Last year, 788 people were shot, further reducing the number of shooting victims in New Jersey, the report says.

Fatal shootings are down 40% in New Jersey over the last four years, and in the past two years the state has seen the total number of shootings “reach an all-time low,” Attorney General Matthew Platkin said in a statement to NJ Spotlight News.

“These substantial decreases can be attributed to a multi-pronged approach that builds upon the courageous and dedicated work of our law enforcement officers to also include over $120 million of investments in community violence intervention — programming that puts trained professionals at critical points of intervention like the hospital bedside and on the streets, preventing further violence and victimization,” Platkin said.
Layoffs, program cuts

But community-based violence intervention programs in New Jersey and across the country have had to lay off employees and in some cases end services altogether after the U.S. Department of Justice abruptly canceled hundreds of ongoing grants in April. That work is being reduced or shuttered altogether as the region prepares for excessive heat. Crime increases and shootings occur more often when temperatures rise outside, academics and researchers have noted.

By taking away funding from these organizations and leading to their collapse, the federal government is also now taking away the little bit of trust these organizations may have helped to build with other institutional structures or organizations, including local hospitals, Jason Williams, a professor of justice studies at Montclair State University, said.
“This is going to have a colossal effect and all kinds of collateral consequences that I don’t even think people are really seeing or talking about right now,” said Williams.

On Tuesday, Platkin, along with 21 attorneys general and the state of Pennsylvania, filed a multistate lawsuit challenging the Trump administration’s “illegal attempts” to end federal funding to states for a wide variety of programs, including those combating violent crime, according to a press release from the New Jersey attorney general’s office.

Community violence intervention and prevention services provide peer support, counseling, mentorship and conflict mediation. The goal is to improve people’s lives in neighborhoods where violence is common. The programs promote positive behavioral change and reduce the likelihood that people who are victims of community violence will commit or promote violence themselves.
‘So important’ during summer

And the programs work, say the experts who study them and the people whose lives have been changed by them. In a recent interview with NJ Spotlight News, Racquel Romans-Henry of Salvation and Social Justice said violence disruption teams are “so important” during summer because the programs offer outlets and resources to young people.

“It gives us access to the communities in a way that we may not have access to in other parts of the year when people tend to be indoors. And quite frankly, the need is incredibly great,” said Romans-Henry, the director of policy for the Trenton-based nonprofit.
Salvation and Social Justice runs the Trenton Restorative Street Team, which provides violence prevention and intervention programming through education and advocacy, among other offerings.

“More than ever, I think the support of these teams is crucial,” said Romans-Henry. “One of the things we continue to advocate for is not just increased state support, but increased local and county support for these crisis response teams and using cannabis dollars to support those teams as well,” Romans-Henry said.

Gov. Phil Murphy’s budget proposal for the fiscal year that begins July 1 includes $25.5 million in revenues from marijuana sales to support hospital and community-based violence intervention programs, according to a state budget document.
Community trust

Providers of community-based violence intervention programs across the state responded to a total of 688 violent incidents in 2024, according to Tara Oliver, a spokesperson for the attorney general’s office.

Other programs working to prevent and reduce violence this summer include thePaterson Healing Collective, a hospital-based violence intervention programin Passaic County. The healing collective pairs medical staff at St. Joseph’s University Medical Center in Paterson with community members who have built trusting relationships with their peers tomentor victims of gun violence— many of whom are young men of color — and limit retaliation among them.

Earlier this month, the Paterson Healing Collective hosted its fourth annual Paterson Healing Fest concert in the city. The event, which included live music and free food, took place on “Wear Orange” weekend, a national effort spearheaded by the Everytown for Gun Safety Support Fund “to honor survivors of gun violence and demand a future free from gun violence.” Around 500 people attended, according to Liza Chowdhury, executive director of the Paterson Healing Collective and Reimagining Justice Inc.

The day after the event, June 8, the healing collective began its second annual “Summer Peace Challenge,” according to Casey Melvin, the director of both field operations and the crisis response team for the collective. The challenge encourages every neighborhood in the city, especially those considered to be high-crime areas, to take part in a 90-day contest to lower the number of gun violence incidents and to push for a summer free from shootings and homicides.
The top three neighborhoods that have no gun violence or have the least amount of gun violence by the end of the 90 days will win a block party in their section of the city, according to Melvin.

“The community believes in us and we’re a trusted agency,” Melvin said in a recent interview with NJ Spotlight News. “The more support we receive, the better we’ll do because our end goal is to end gun violence as the slogan for National Wear Orange Day states.”
‘Familiar faces’

The Paterson Healing Collective is “so effective” because staff members are from the community and are “familiar faces” who are going to a hospital bedside after a person has been shot, according to Chowdhury.

Rahshon Dixon is one of those staff members that visits gunshot victims at St. Joseph’s University Medical Center. Dixon said in a recent interview that gunshot victims often face depression after surviving the experience.

“We leave a card, we’ll take their information and give them our information,” Dixon, a safety planning coordinator at the healing collective, said of the hospital visits. The healing collective offers one-on-one and group mental health counseling to gunshot victims, along with many other services, Dixon said.
Providers of hospital-based violence intervention programs worked with over 2,500 people affected by violence in 2024, according to the attorney general’s office.

Violent crime rates and homicide rates have also been down nationally and in New Jersey over the last couple of years due in part to “historic investments” made by the Biden administration and states putting money into violence prevention, according to Daniel Semenza, an associate professor at Rutgers University.

“Community violence intervention and the adjacent hospital-based violence intervention has been a big part of that investment over the last couple of years,” said Semenza, who also serves as the director of research at the New Jersey Gun Violence Research Center.
Semenza noted that violence has decreased at some of the fastest rates nationally since homicide data started being recorded.
However, he said his biggest concern is the reversal of these positive trends due to the federal funding cuts that happened in April.

“The news that is currently still coming out — the quarterly news that you might see from something like the Real-Time Crime Index that is tracking homicide rates on a monthly, quarterly basis — it’s still good news,” said Semenza. “It’s still showing drops in violence throughout the state and throughout the country, but there’s always going to be a lag.”
“My fear is that now in the summer, when there’s a little bit more of a lag time, we might start to see the implications of these funding cuts,” Semenza said.

content_elements.caption: Three NJ Transit buses crashed at the Port Authority bus terminal Wednesday morning, injuring 12 and closing it during the morning rush hour.   (Aristide Economopoulos | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com) NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
content_elements.subtitle: Bus crash  closes Port Authority Bus Terminal

content_elements.content: A multi-bus crash that injured 17 people, closed part of the busy Port Authority Bus terminal and caused delays at the Lincoln Tunnel during the height of the Wednesday morning rush hour.

Port Authority officials said police responded to a crash between three NJ Transit buses at 6:15 a.m. Twelve people sustained minor injuries, and one person was transported to the hospital for further evaluation.
An alert said the crash happened on the third floor of the bus terminal. An investigation is underway to determine the cause of the incident.
NJ Transit CEO Kris Kolluri said 15 passengers and two employees had minor injuries.
Port Authority alerts said the crash has caused 30 minute Lincoln Tunnel delays to New York.
The Route 495 express bus lane (XBL) ramp closed, and all bus traffic has been rerouted to the upper level of the terminal. The XBL reopened at 9:38 a.m.

The crash caused NJ Transit buses traveling to and from the Port Authority Bus Terminal to be diverted to Secaucus Junction, Newark Penn Station and Hoboken Terminal. All trains will stop at Secaucus.
NJ Transit bus tickets and passes are being cross-honored by NJ Transit rail, on New York Waterway ferries at Port Imperial and by PATH at Hoboken, Newark Penn Station and 33rd Street New York.
However trains also experienced a 20 minute delay to and from Penn Station New York due to an earlier disabled NJ Transit train, according to an alert.

content_elements.caption: There was flooding throughout Lakewood after storms that rolled through the area dropped multiple inches of rain in a short amount of time.

affiliation.name: Photo Courtesy of The Lakewood Scoop

by.byline: Photo Courtesy of The Lakewood Scoop
by.name: Photo Courtesy of The Lakewood Scoop

content_elements.subtitle: Lakewood Flooding July 1, 2025
content_elements.creditIPTC: Photo Courtesy of The Lakewood Scoop

content_elements.content: A deluge of rain fell across large swaths of New Jersey on Tuesday night as thunderstorms roiled the state.
Streets across multiple counties were flooded as flash flood warnings were issued for sections of Monmouth and Ocean counties during the heaviest stretches of rain.

Howell Township got hit the hardest, seeing 5.22 inches of rain fall between Tuesday and 8 a.m. on Wednesday, data from the Community Collaborative Rain, Hail & Snow Network, known as CoCoRaHS, shows.
Woodland Township in Burlington County saw 4.77 inches, the second highest in the state, while Neptune City in Monmouth County came in third, with 3.88 inches of rain.
And the rain isn’t over yet. Thunderstorms are likely for most of New Jersey on Wednesday and Thursday, primarily in the southern half of the state.
Use the chart to see how much rain fell in your town. Data is based on reports from the Rutgers NJ Weather Network and CoCoRaHS.

original.longBio: Katie Kausch is a data reporter for NJ Advance Media, covering a range of topics including education, politics and health. Before becoming a data reporter, Katie was a breaking news reporter with a focus on the courts in Morris and Middlesex counties. She holds a degree in Communication Arts and Journalism from Marymount Manhattan College, and has won multiple New Jersey Press Association awards. Katie looks forward to making New Jersey a better place to live through her reporting.
